dialog.text: Okay, Helix. Why are you staring at me?
I'm waiting to see if you become a cannibal.

dialog.action: lays the fork down and stands up
dialog.text: That's it. I'm out of here.

223.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/dining area

224.chapter: Trip to "The Golden Trough", the finest in bad cuisine.

dialog.text: YOU CAN'T LEAVE! I PAID FOR THIS! I PAID FOR THIS!
She can't leave! I paid for two people! Now what am I supposed to do?
You could eat twice as much.
Ugh! Why is it always the captain who has to suffer for the actions of his crew?

225.chapter: Trip to "The Golden Trough", the finest in bad cuisine.

dialog.text: Helix, go after her. See if she wants to come back.
I've let people down before, but this time I actually feel bad about it.
I hope it's just the food. This would be a terrible time in life to start developing morals.

226.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.action: spots Florence and wonders what she's doing
lurks behind and peers over some bushes
looks over the bushes, sees a herd of deers there and realizes Florence is trying to hunt them

dialog.text: RUN FOR YOUR LIVES, DEER!

dialog.action: gets scared by the unexpected sceaming of Helix

dialog.text: I'm being your conscience, just like Jiminy Cricket.
In the original story, Pinocchio squished that cricket.

226.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

227.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Waaah! You want to eat Bambi!
RRRR. Okay, how about a compromise? Do you have any objections about a deer that's been road killed?
Suppose I don't want to compromise?
Then I'll rip you into tiny pieces and take my pick of the herd.
Road kill it is.
I like dealing with Florence. She makes it so easy to make a decision.

228.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.action: without attracting attention, unhinges a square tile (part of the road)
dialog.text: Helix! Look! It's an obvious distraction!

dialog.action: looks in the direction pointed out by Florence
dialog.text: Where?

dialog.action: goes running the other direction with the tile held over her head
from the general direction of where Florence ran
dialog.text: I don't see any obvious distractions.
WHAM!

dialog.action: satisfied stands next to a dead deer which lays there with the tile on its head

dialog.text: Road Kill.
Hey, wait a minute...

229.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.action: replaced the tile into the road

dialog.text: Now what do we do?
Well, we need a place to get this deer ready to eat.
Surgical strike. We go in, we get permission, we fix lunch, we get out.
Culinary commando Helix! Standing by to be polite and cook ass, Ma'am!

229.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

230.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Uh, guys. There's a big dog, wearing a dress, asking if she can use the kitchen.
Sure Ryan. You go tell that big dog she can use whatever she wants.
Food fumes causing hallucinations again?
We have got to get that kitchen better ventilated.

230.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

231.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: They said we could use the kitchen.
I'm ready. I found a funny hat.
This grill needs to be cleaned before we can use it.
Is it bad?
Helix, I could cook meat here with the chemical burns alone.

231.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/kitchen

232.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: I didn't think you were going to cook the meat.
It's safer with wild deer to clean and cook the meat thoroughly. It's very easy for a body to pick up parasites.
Even political bodies?
Especially political bodies. In those, the mass of the parasites often outweighs the mass of the host.

232.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/kitchen

233.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: What's that?
This is the best part of any animal.
AAAHH! IT'S THE LIVER! YOU'RE GOING TO EAT BAMBI'S LIVER!
I used to enjoy mealtime conversations.
As soon as I can find some, I'm going to toss my cookies!

233.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/kitchen

234.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Eeew! Yuck! Gross!
Oh, hush. This is no different from what you guys do.
Haven't you ever visited a robot recycling yard?
Well, uhm...
Don't tell me you're one of those robots who faint at the sight of battery acid?
It's not my fault. I just have a sensible nature.

235.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Something smells good.
Yeah, I think it comes from our place.
OH, CRUD!
When you get scents like that coming from our kitchen, you know there's trouble!
[TROUGH PARKING]

235.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

236.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.action: walks past the two puzzled cooks
dialog.text: Hello. Thanks again for letting me use your place.
Did you just see a wolf in a blue dress carrying a beautifully prepared grilled liver plater and prime cut of venison steak?
Yep.
We must be imagining things.
Right. No way food like that could ever come out of our kitchen.

236.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/kitchen

237.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Hi, Sam.
Hey, that's liver! How did you get a hold of that?
It's easy. You take the deer, slice open the belly, move the intestines to one side, then reach into the abdominal cavity and...

dialog.action: suddenly feels queasy, holds a hand before his mouth and runs for the restroom
dialog.text: Urp!
I know just how he feels. With good food like this available, I'd purge my previous meal too.

237.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/dining area

238.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: Feeling better?
Yeah. Let's get moving.
[MEN] [WOMEN]

dialog.action: from inside the men's room some cursing are heard
dialog.text: [WOMEN] [OTHER]

238.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/restrooms

239.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: What? People have actually been banned from "The Golden Trough"?

dialog.action: reads what's written under one of the pictures displayed
dialog.text: "Bruno Bunkleyutz. Banned for stealing customers."

dialog.action: reads what's written under one of the pictures displayed
dialog.text: "Dave Schumacher. Banned for eating too much and failure to properly amuse a cat."

dialog.action: reads what's written under one of the pictures displayed
dialog.text: "Sam Starfall. Reserved. Hasn't done anything yet, but we know he will."
It's good to know that some people still have faith in me.

239.place: short time later, The Golden Trough

240.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.action: plays a catchy tune on his vocal speakers

dialog.text: What's that song you're playing?
I don't know. I downloaded it from the net this morning and now can't get it out of my head.
It's either a really catchy tune or a computer virus, I'm not sure which.

240.place: short time later, The Golden Trough

241.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: I'm hungry again.

dialog.action: looks towards Florence over at the table
dialog.text: Florence looks like she's enjoying her food. She might give you some if you ask.
I'm the captain. I don't ask. But I think I know how I can get her to offer.

dialog.action: goes over and places his chin on the table, making 'puppy-dog-eyes' towards Florence

241.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/dining area

242.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: He wants some of my food. I wasn't sure before, but I am now.
Thank you for your confidence, captain. I accept.
Hold on. Did I just miss something?
Waits until I'm almost done eating, then checks with me before eating himself. You don't acknowledge an Alpha Wolf more clearly than that.

243.chapter: How to catch a deer. Sort of.

dialog.text: I'm going to pack up the rest of the deer. Please bring the truck around when you're done.
Not bad. Not aged enough for a scavenger's taste, but a few days in the sun could fix that.
The only problem will be getting the right condiments. It's hard to believe, but you can't even find gourmet maggots in this town.
Sam, there's a man from Ecosystems Unlimited asking about the deer Florence ate.
Thanks, Helix. I'll take care of it.
Florence isn't supposed to be on this planet. If this guy's looking for her, I'll need to throw him off track. I'll probably have to deceive and lie to a lot of people before this is over.
Life is good.

244.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/dining area

dialog.text: Hello. You had some questions about a deer?
No longer. I've already figured this out.
See these tracks? Toes only. And here? A hand print. There's only one thing that moves on its toes and can leave a hand print.
You mean...?
Exactly. This deer was killed by a feral ballerina!

245.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

dialog.text: A ballerina killed the deer. Of course! It's obvious now.
Yes. Poor thing was probably abandoned by a dance company and went feral in order to survive.
Feral ballerinas can be very dangerous. A pack of them can strip an arts endowment to the bone in seconds!
Are you going to capture it?
We'll try. Unless it's a Prima Donna. Those get along so poorly with others it's more merciful just to shoot them.
I'm off to file my report. Thanks for your help.
You're welcome.
That was simple. All I had to do to deceive him was agree with him.
I hope the next person I lie to is more suspicious. If everyone is this easy, I'm going to lose my edge.
Hi, Sam. I've got the deer cut up and packed away. Do you mind if I take a few minutes to clean up?
Sure. No Problem.
Thanks. I'll be right back.
When someone who's covered with blood and carrying a knife asks me politely, I'll usually say "Yes".

248.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside

dialog.text: Wow. There's a lot of meat on a deer.
I'm surprised Florence was able to cut it up without Helix complaining.
I guess it helps knowing what you need to bag first.

249.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside/by Pop Rivit's truck

dialog.text: That was fun! I've never been on a date before.
What makes you think you were on a date?
From observing you.
When you go out, what's the first thing a woman wants to do?
Put a bag over my head. Hmm. Maybe you were on a date.

250.place: >, The Golden Trough/outside/by Pop Rivit's truck

dialog.text: No, no. This is ridiculous.
Why would Florence want to date you when I'm around?
Maybe because she knows I'm a beautiful person inside.
{while they wait}

251.place: >, The Golden Trough/outside/by Pop Rivit's truck

dialog.text: Does it feel weird to you for us to be waiting here?
Yeah.
Normally when we leave a restaurant, we're being chased by an angry mob.
That's it! I knew something didn't seem right.

252.place: >, The Golden Trough/outside/by Pop Rivit's truck

dialog.text: Sigh. That was clumsy of me. I should have cleaned up before I talked to Sam.
At least no humans saw me. A deer needs to be bagged quickly to prevent waste, but many find the process to be upsetting.
In a way, meat is like government money. People like getting it, but they don't like thinking about where it actually comes from.

dialog.action: as she leaves the women's room, a little boy points at her

dialog.text: DOGGY! DOGGY! DOGGY!

dialog.action: smiles and holds out his arms to get a hug

dialog.text: Children almost always react to me like I'm some sort of theme park character.
And for that, I have no complaints at all.

254.place: at the same time, The Golden Trough/restrooms

dialog.action: walks past a wall and reads what's written on it
dialog.text: Arthur C. Clarke]

dialog.action: goes on to read the next quote
dialog.text: Barry Gehm]

dialog.action: takes a marker and adds a quote herself
dialog.text: Florence Ambrose]
TROUGH]

255.place: short time later, The Golden Trough

dialog.text: Looks like we're ready to go.
You know I liked this place.
Any restaurant I can leave with half my weight in doggie bags is all right by me.

256.place: short time later, The Golden Trough/outside/by Pop Rivit's truck

dialog.text: After we put the meat into the freezer, we should return the truck.
Return the truck? You want to go see Mr. Rivet and give him back his truck?
Certainly. We don't need it anymore, and it would be impolite not to thank him.
Impolite. After borrowing his truck without permission again, I'm willing to bet Mr. Rivet is going to violate every notion of "polite" Florence ever had.
How about this? You drop us off at the ship. Helix and I can put the food away while you return the truck.
Sounds fine. It's just a short walk back.
Also, you know how some guys like to insult each other? Don't be surprised if Pop Rivet shoots at you a little.
SHOOTS AT ME?
You know, friendly like.

258.place: >, Pop Rivit's truck/on the way back to Sam's ship

dialog.text: Your friend actually shoots at you?
It's no big deal.
He hasn't hit me yet, and his shotgun is only loaded with rock salt.
Of course, when you need to wear a spacesuit, it really doesn't matter much if the holes are made by lead or rock salt.

259.place: >, Pop Rivit's truck/on the way back to Sam's ship

dialog.text: Okay, the safest way to return the truck is to go about 30 kph and put on the cruise control.
Aim for a large building. About a kilometer away, jump off the truck and run for home. The crash will let Pop Rivet know it's back.
How about if I just park the truck and knock on his door?
I don't know. Your way sounds kind of dangerous.

260.place: later, Pop Rivit's truck/near Sam's ship

dialog.text: The elevator works?
Yep. All it needed was power.
Excellent. How long do you think it'll be before Florence has the ship ready to fly?
With the port fusion engine fixed, it can fly right now.
He's smiling. That's usually a good thing. So why are all my self preservation routines coming on line?

261.place: short time later, Sam's ship/cargo bay

dialog.text: Have you ever flown a spaceship?
No, but I have flown a dirigible.
The principle's the same. Make something hot the ship goes up. It's not rocket science.
Uhmm...
Okay, so maybe it is rocket science. But how hard can it be?
Our ship...isn't like...a dirigible. Dirigibles go up because of helium.
We have a fusion engine. When it makes helium, our ship goes up. See? There's no major difference between our ship and a dirigible.
I think...I will only...talk to Florence about technology. When I talk to Sam..my brain keeps trying to lock up.
Hey! The door won't push open! Florence locked us out of the Cockpit!
No, wait! She wouldn't do that. There must be a way in. We have power. We can get in by PUSHING THE "OPEN" BUTTON!
Don't you see, Helix. It was a test! By figuring out how to get in, she must know we're ready to fly the ship!
I want to get into the air as soon as possible.
I know what to do! I know what to do! Press that button!
YAAAH!
I'm actually learning how this ship works. Sam must be so proud of me.

dialog.action: runs to where Sam lays on his face after hitting the ground

dialog.text: Helix. I'm going to say this slowly to make sure you understand completely. Take the chair and put it back into the ship.
'CAUSE I WANT TO DO THAT AGAIN!

266.place: short time later, near Sam's ship

dialog.text: The seat's back, the ceiling panel's duct taped in place. Why can't I eject?
Explosive bolt error? Why should the ejection seat care about the ceiling panels?

dialog.character: Sam's ship's computer {later known as "Essi" aka: Savage Chicken}
dialog.text: More info.
Two words. Roof pizza.
Okaaay. I guess that is an important safety feature.
Let's get the ship flying! Hey, this sounds impressive. "Initiate Tritium injection".

dialog.character: Sam's ship's computer {later known as "Essi" aka: Savage Chicken}
dialog.text: Warning: High pressure detected. Tritium injection system is for start up only. System is now isolated and off line.
I've noticed that once you find something working, it doesn't stay working very long.
Yeah. I'll have to talk to Florence about the quality of her repairs.
Activate iron jets.

dialog.character: Sam's ship's computer {later known as "Essi" aka: Savage Chicken}
dialog.text: Warning: Magnetic scoops can not be used in the atmosphere. Command aborted.
Helix. Look at this command program. It's learning from my mistakes and adapting itself to my piloting skills.
Wow! It's not letting you near any of the vital systems anymore.
Bloddy software! I don't want a program that learns! I want a program that stays stupid!
Nuts! I'm being locked out of everything!
Now it banned me from the kitchen! Just how dangerous does this program think I am?
Press here. It'll say.
AS DANGEROUS AS A SPIDER MONKEY WITH A NAIL GUN!?
It's also recommending I take away your tooth brush before someone gets hurt.
Having any luck?
Luck! That's it! That's what we've been doing wrong!
We're only having bad luck here. Do you know why?
Because we haven't read any of the instruction manuals?
No! Of course not! We're having bad luck because we're trying to fly the ship before it's been christened!
I knew we had some wine. At a dollar a bottle, it's kind of expensive. But our ship deserves the very best.
What? It's in an unbreakable pastic bottle! We can't christen the ship with this!
This way, Helix! I know how to fix it.
If there's one thing I've learned, when Sam's involved, NOTHING is unbreakable.

272.place: short time later, Sam's ship/kitchen area

dialog.text: Here we go. John Jones Monroevian Moonshine.
Fine sipping Whiskey and high explosive. You bought this for me, Helix, remember?
I remember. That stuff cost me an arm and a leg!
Yeah. You were lucky it was just a shot glass you dropped or you would have lost a lot more.

273.place: short time later, Sam's ship/Sam's room

dialog.text: We mix a little of the moonshine in with the wine and viola!
A highly volatile mix that will both break the bottle and maintain tradition.
I don't like this tradition.
What? Christening the ship?
Oh! Sorry. I thought you meant out tradition of blowing ourselves up.
The wind is really starting to pick up.
Yeah. Let's get the ship christened and get back inside.
I really like the idea of naming our ship after a bird of prey.
We'll call her "THE SAVAGE CHICKEN"
I bet we fly like a chicken too.

275.place: short time later, outside Sam's ship

dialog.text: I name this ship "The Savage Chicken"!
BOOM
Did you see the way the ship jumped up when we christened it? It can't wait to get into the air.
Myself, I can't wait to get back onto the ground.

276.place: short time later, outside Sam's ship

277.chapter: Is Sam smarter than the ship's computer?

dialog.text: Now that the ship is christened, we'll be flying in no time.
Hmm. This is odd. I'm still locked out of the system and I have an error message.

dialog.action: reads the error message out aloud
dialog.text: "Moronic user error. Details: If I had hands, I would slap you silly."
It must be a common fault. I see that error message all the time.

278.chapter: Is Sam smarter than the ship's computer?

dialog.text: Helix! Helix! Come quick!I've got the ship flying!
We're at 1500 meters. I found a way around the computer lockout and took off a couple of minutes ago.
Program running. Tutorial: Flight simulation.
I didn't know it was possible to fly a ship this smoothly. I'm a piloting genius!

279.chapter: Is Sam smarter than the ship's computer?

dialog.text: Hey. This isn't real. I'm running a flight program.
Computer, end all virtual reality simulations.

dialog.action: covers Sam's eyes with his hands from behind

dialog.text: AAAAAAAAHHH!
Don't DO that! You want to give me a heart attack?
I've crashed half the systems trying to get into the computer. When Florence gets back, I know what she's going to say.
Sam, I see you've been trying to get the ship flying. Good job. We need to move as soon as possible.
That! Yeah! I knew she was going to say exactly that!
Oh, you big fibber!
What's going on? What's the rush?
There's a hurrikane coming. We need to move the ship to the spaceport's armored hanger.
You're getting the ship ready to fly?
Yes. If we don't move, we'll be destroyed.
Wow. Ever since we christened this ship, my luck just keeps getting better and better.

281.place: short time later, Savage Chicken/corridor/door to Florence's room

dialog.text: Hey! Wait! What happened with Pop Rivet?
Your friend wasn't home. I left the truck in his underground garage.
I'm going to have to talk to him about security, though. He has a good system, but the way it's installed allowed me to bypass it with just three jump wires.
She can do things like that and she's completely honest. What a waste of talent.
Helix! Great news! We're going to be flying into a hurricane!
We can't be held responsible. Any mistake we make, we can blame on the storm.
That's only if the damage we do is less than the damage from the hurricane.
Oooh. Good point. I'll try to fly conservatively so that doesn't happen.
Okay, let's log on and see what our status is.
[FLORENCE! You're back! Hooray!]
Sam and Helix must have taught the computer to do this. What a sweet pair of guys.

284.place: at the same time, Savage Chicken/cockpit

dialog.action: a Diagram of the turbines is displayed on the screen
dialog.text: Cross connect complete. Port reactor is now supplying both solid state engines.
Air turbines on line. Life support on line. And just as important...
Coffee maker on line.
Sam, where are you going?
Outside. The computer asked me to.
It wants me to stand as close as I can in front of the air jet engines while it starts them and does a 100% power test.
Come with me, Sam. I want to look at this computer.
But Florence, the test! It says this has to be done to protect the safety of all humanity!
Are you sure? The computer is trying to kill me?
Yes. It's an old human build system and sees you as a threat to its makers.
Well, that's only because it doesn't really know me.
I'm sure if we have a private little talk, we can work everything out.
Give me the wrench, Sam. We need this computer.
Computer, now that we're alone, we need to talk. You're not looking at the big picture here.
The biggest threat to an advanced species is complacency. They become so comfortable that they lose their ability to adapt. A big change comes along and they go extinct.
By selflessly providing a constant source of chaos, I keep this from happening. True, it's bad in the short run. But in the long run, people like me are vital to the survival of the human race.
Great news! The computer doesn't want to kill me anymore. Now all it wants is a really big bottle of Aspirin!
This ship's not fully repaired and we're about to fly into a hurricane. I don't think I've ever been so nervous.

dialog.action: looks at Sam, who is being silly and makes funny faces at Helix

dialog.text: And then there's Sam. So confident in his piloting abilities that even in this situation he can joke around. I really should try to be more like him.
The computer just unlocked the ship's controls. All flight systems are showing green. I'm ready to fly.
No longer will I be earthbound! Limitless new possibilities await!
Why, it's almost as if one book in my life has ended and a new one is just about to begin.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: Good evening. This is Rants Freely of Overhype News, bringing you the latest on hurricane Joe.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: As you know, weather is a chaotic system. This entire hurricane might have had its start in the flapping of a butterfly's wings.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.action: shows a picture of Sam in the background
dialog.text: But since we like butterflies, we've decided to blame everything on this guy instead.

291.place: at the same time, Overhype News studio

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: Hurricane Joe is now moving inland after picking up strength and Alferio's pasta barge.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: If you're in a yellow area, evacuate or seek shelter immediately. If you're in a red area and not in an armored shelter, please listen carefully.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News

dialog.text: This is just like the simulation. Increase power. Pull back on the stick.
And we're flying! She did it! Florence fixed the ship! That woman is a genius!
Of course, I'm not going to let her know I think that. She might start making unreasonable demands, like wanting to get paid or something.

293.place: at the same time, Savage Chicken/cockpit

dialog.action: flies through the storm, on collision course with a small flying camera of Overhype News
dialog.text: [OVERHYPE NEWS]

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: What happened?
We've lost skycam one!
Satellite view coming up. We've got a confirmed Sam Launch!
SAM! YOU JUST HIT A NEWS CAMERA!
That should end any doubts of my piloting ability. Got it on the first try.
Okay, let's see what this ship can do.
First, it's capable of making me really, really, nauseous.
[TI LT]
Whoo! How's that for piloting, Florence? I just flew inder a bridge!

dialog.action: the bridge literally flies by behind the Savage Chicken
dialog.text: {We hear what's spoken in the cockpit}
Flying under a bridge only counts if it's intentional.
Now, now. Let's not get hung up on technicalities.
I've found a path around the worst of the storm cells. It's been approved and the spaceport is expecting us in five minutes.
Approved? You mean they know we're coming?
That is the point of filing a flight plan.
My only hope is that no one on duty knows me.
There are some nice folks at this spaceport. A fire control radar just locked on to us. We can follow the beam right in.
A second radar has locked on. With two beams guiding us, we can land on a dime.
This is odd. Why aren't they shooting at us?
Why aren't we shooting at them?
Budget interlock. the computer recognizes Sam and won't let us shoot a missile that's worth more than the predicted value of his ship.
So what are ge supposed to do? Take him down with rubber bands and paper clips?
Still to expensive. The computer will only authorize up to spit wads.
Sigh. Landing clearance granted.
Thank you, tower. There will be a delay as we're responding to a distress call.
YOU!? WHO!? WHAT!? WHY!?
It's the duty of every citizen to respond in an emergency. Uploading new flight plan now.
I thought you said that was Sam's ship up there!
I'm checking. It's still showing as Sam's ship. Must be a glitch in the system or something.
Florence! What are you doing? I don't want to rescue people? I want to land and show off my ship!
They're right in the path of a storm cell. No one else can respond in time.
I want to rescue people!
Ship protocol requires rescue.
Then it's decided. We're doing this rescue.
Call me old fashioned. But as captain of this ship, I really think I should have some say in how it's run.
I'll need your help in the cargo bay.
Oh boy! I get to help rescue people!
It's taken me years to bring Helix around to my way of thinking. Now florence comes along with her talk about honesty, nobility, self sacrifice.
How am I supposed to keep Helix on the straight and narrow when she keeps appealing to his base instincts like that?
The cargo bay doors will be open. We'll need to tie ourselves off.
Why?
Whoop! Flying obstacle! Hang on, guys!
Okay. Now I see why.
One day, Sam will help me make a point without it being painful.

302.place: short time later, Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.action: sends Sam a map to the small screen in front of the controls
dialog.text: Here's the area map. There's a shelter and a medical facility nearby if we can't make it to the spaceport.
Satellite returns show the area is flooded. I hope they'Re on a building, but we may have to fish them out of the water.
This was just a stupid rescue mission in a hurricane. But now that fishing is involved, it may actually become something I can brag about.

304.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.action: points a search-light at one of the buildings

dialog.text: Do you see anyone?
No. They probably don't know we're out here waiting for them.
I still can't believe humans would design a starship and not give it a horn!
Sam, if they had known you'd be flying it, I'm sure they would have.

305.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: The building computer says three people are inside. I'm going to have to go down there.
Shouldn't I go down?
You're not water proof. And id worst comes to worst, I can swim. You can't.
It's not fair. Organic beings are so much tougher and more mobile than robots.
It's the advantage we get for using designs that have undergone eighty million years of testing.

306.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: What's that?
This? I added a side handle onto a flashlight so I could hold it in my mouth.
This way it keeps my hands free and the flashlight is always pointing in the direction I'm looking.
So, what do you think?
I think that I've never seen anything so stupid and so practical in all my life.

307.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Phone check. Sam, Helix, can you hear me?
Hello, Flo. I can hear you fine.
Sam! You're using an unsecured phone line! They'll know we're here! Quick, turn on your scrambler!
Hi there! Have you ever thought about canging your long distance company?
Switch to mine!
No, mine!
Too late.

308.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Goodbye! Go! We don't want your product!
But... But...
Telemarketers are the most rude, annoying, and deceitful peple I have ever met!
I kind of have a soft spot for them.
It's the only job I ever applied for where they said I was overqualified.

309.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Now it's time for fishing with Flo.
Ha, Ha, Helix.

dialog.action: some kind of three-finned seamonster passes by in the water underneath
dialog.text: Though I must admit, I do feel like a worm on a hook here.
I really, really, didn't need to see that.

310.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.action: A gust of wind violently gives the Savage Chicken a good shake midair
dialog.text: This shouldn't be hard. It looks like I can get in through that roof access door.
Or a window. Getting in through a window works, too.

311.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Water pressure outside. Air inside. This place isn't going to last long.
An updated meeting schedule? This is only five minutes old. Who could possibly be so out of touch with reality?
Oh, No! I'm here to rescue middle management.

312.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Mr. Kornada! The building is going to collapse! We have to leave!
You're not telling me what I want to hear.
If we don't go, we will all die.
That's not on today's schedule. If it's not on the schedule, it's not going to happen.
Whoever made it so that robots can't harm humans couldn't have had him in mind!
Just keep him going. A few more comments like that and we should be able to reclassify him as talking fungus.

312.place: at the same time, office building/Kornada's office

313.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: DOGGY!
Qwerty, that is no ordinary dog.
You know what I am?
In a dangerous situation like this? Of course. It's obvious.
RESCUE DOGGY!
Maybe Sam was right. We should have left them after we could only get their voice mail.

314.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Allow me to introduce ourselves. I'm Dvorak and my standardized friend is Qwerty.
That doesn't sound like productive work going on!
There's the reason why we're still here. We can't leave a human in danger and he refuses to believe there's a crisis.
Okay, I think I know what to do.
Please tell me it involves evisceration. We'd have to stop you, of course. But I'm willing to bet we could slow our reaction times way down!

315.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Mr. Kornada, do you understand what's happening here?
I don't have to understand. I just tell my people what to do.
Don't you want the truth?
I CAN'T HANDLE THE TRUTH!
Uh, oh. A management training certificate. This man is forever lost to us.
You're not on my organizational chart. Are you an incompetent worker or someone I need to suck up to?

316.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: We need to get you to the roof for evacuation. Did you know there's a very, very, small possibility the janitor is up there smoking a cigarette?
Egads! I must go immideately and take twenty minutes to ensure a minimum wage employee isn't wasting a single second of precious company time!
You've dealt with management before, haven't you?
Please, I feel unclean enough as it is.

317.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Mr. Kornada, hold on a moment.
What are you doing?
I'm putting you into a lifting harness. There are a few simple directions you'll need to follow.
I'm a manager. I don't follow directions, I give them.
You know, you're really making me wish this thing had child proof fasteners.

318.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: I'm getting wet.
That's because it's raining.
There's a hurricane going on.
Is anything being done about this hurricane thing?
I believe Enthropic Decay is already working on it.
Ah, yes. Good man. Be sure that he sends me a progress report.

319.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: Helix, he's attached. Bring him up.
A telephone.
I need to check my voice mail. I'm sure that you understand. my needs are more important than yours.
Hey!
I'll get you a stick and cover my eyes. You whack him until he drops the phone. It'll be just like hitting a pinata in an ugly suit.

320.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: I need you to contact my ship. It's the 1071CCN.
Got it.
Where's your friend?
Qwerty? He was right behind me. He must have run into a problem.
Hey! Where's the instruction manual for this thing?

321.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: You can't climb stairs?
I always take the elevator. I don't have any drivers installed.
Come on up. It's simple.
Maybe for you organic types. When it comes to real world stuff, everything is so easy for you.
Right. A robot stuck in a building because he can't go up the stairs. This is so easy for me.
See what I mean? I'd have no idea what to do in this situation.

322.chapter: We came here to rescue this?

dialog.text: How are you going to get me up the stairs?
CRUMPLE
Adrenaline.
Good. Now I know how to go up stairs for the next time.
Move! Move! Move!
This building is all cross supports. Once one part goes, the whole thing goes pretty fast.
How fast?
That fast! Wow! My whole life just flashed before my eyes.
Mine's still flashing. I've got to buy some faster memory.

323.place: short time later, beneath the Savage Chicken

dialog.text: Wow! The whole building collapsed in seconds.
Where's the doggy?
I think she went in the water.
Egad! This is horrible! This is terrible! This is a disaster!
I'm missing a meeting.

324.place: short time later, Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: I have to get to the spaceport immediately. There's a meeting going on.
I must attend alll meetings, no matter how trivial. It's how I validate my entire existence.
So if you don't attend this meeting, you don't exist?
I eat donuts, therefore I am.
Sam! Sam! Florence is in the water! Doggy overboard!
Captain, I need to get to the spaceport immediately. Money is no objective since it won't be giong to the emoloyees.
Florence knows how to swim, right?
SAM!
Wah!
Florence will be fine. Look. The water is five Degrees Celsius. (41 Degrees Farenheit) With her body weight, she has a survival time of... under 20 minutes.

dialog.action: stops, realizing what he just said

dialog.text: I'm turning down money. I'm acually turning down money. This is a command decision that will haunt me the rest of my life.
I take it we're headed to the spaceport?
No. We need to rescue our engineer.
What!? You consider saving someone's life more important than my being at a meeting to determine the propper distribution of paper clips?
You people have no sense of priorities!

328.place: short time later, Savage chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: I must attend this meeting. I am a manager. Managers manipulate people, and robots are easier to manipulate than most.
Urk! The pain! My chest! I think I'm having a heart attack!
WHOO HOOO!
YEA!
Not the reaction I was hoping for.
You can't delay getting medical care for a heart attack victim, can you?
But if we leave now, the doggy will drown.
I don't want to do this, but... Mr. Kornada is human. The doggy... isn't.
Fastest medical care is at the spaceport. Trying... to resist... No, instructions... too clear.
Ahhhh! We've got to get Mr. Kornada to the spaceport immediately!
Damn our programming!
Oh the weather started getting rough, the tiny ship was tossed.
Ahhh! We're taking over the ship! We've got to get Mr. Kornada to the spaceport immediately!
Less than an hour in command and already I'm having my first mutiny. When starship captains are remembered, I bet I'm going to be legendary.
We've got to get Mr. Kornada to the spaceport!
That's what I want to do!
But I have to rescue Florence before she drowns!
That's what we want to do!
This battle would be much more intense if both sides weren't trying to lose.
Oh no! I've got his legs! Hurry, get Sam a wrench so he can club me!
Victory! Horrible, horrible victory!
You can't do this! You can't leave Florence!
She saved your life! If it weren't for her, you'd be in the water seing so many fishes, you'd think you were stuck on screen saver!
She's not here because she went back to get you!
When this is done, I'm going to need all my guilt chips overclocked.
I'm locked out of the control room. I can't sabotage the ship because then we'd all drown and it still wouldn't help Florence.
There's only one thing to do in a situation like this!
I've got to find Mr. Kornada and take him for everything he's got!
I hoped the roof would have lasted longer, but at least I got the two robots are safety.
Still I'm sure any canine would agree with me that this situation is completely unfair.
I already took a bath today.

335.place: at the same time, in the water

dialog.text: The ship looks like it's having control problems. Now they're headed back to the spaceport.
It's the right thing to do, but that must have been an agonizing decision, having to leave a crew member behind for the safety of the ship.
Poor Sam. If I survive this, I'll have to think of some way to make it up to him.
Wet fabric holds air. I just need to kick off my boots and tie a knot in the end of my pants legs.
Fill it with air and i've got a workable life jacket. From the ship's map, wind and current are pushing me towards land. I should be able to find shelter there.
Considering that I'm in my underwear in near freezing water during a hurricane, I think I'm doing pretty well.
We have emergency landing clearance. The tower has control of the ship. There's nothing more we can do.
We should have free will back in a minute.
I really hate this part. Here, have a stick .
Our designers call this positive reinforcement. I call it adding insult to injury.
Bad robot! Bad! If I were a good robot, my programmed safeguards wouldn't have to take over.
It's like you said. You need to reduce your taxes.
You're agreeing with me, so your conclusions must be valid.
The reason your taxes are so high is because your profits are so high. I can fix that.
I'm also impressed by how you treat your people.
They wouldn't be called human resources if they weren't meant to be strip mined.

339.place: at the same time, Savage Chicken/kitchen area

dialog.text: We're taking Mr. Kornada to medical. He's having a heart attack.
No, he's not.
Yes I am. Gasp. Gasp. Oh, the pain.
Hey, I've given enough people heart attacks to know what they look like, and that is not a heart attack.
You lied to us!?!
I motivated you. My goal was met. The way you're acting, you'd think that was a bad thing.

340.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

dialog.text: You faked a heart attack and made me leave behind the person who saved my life? I'm going to...

dialog.action: starts hitting his head against a wall
dialog.text: Bad robot! Bad! If I were a good robot, my programmed safeguards wouldn't have to take over.
Bam Bam Bam
Arrgh! I can't do anything and he knows it. I can's take this. I'm turning myself off.

dialog.action: being deactivated he keels over backwards hitting on Mr. Kornada's right foot with his head on the way down

dialog.text: We're at the spaceport. Mr. Starfall, once a job is done we have a standard policy for dealing with contractors. Please bend over.
We give them a swift kick in the pants and then wonder why they don't want to work for us again. Have a nice day.
Despite being the most admirable human I've ever met, he didn't pay me, and for that I must have revenge.

342.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: Hi, Mr. Kornada. Captain Sam gave us the most wonderful talk. We're taking you to the doctor.
Go away. I feel fine.
People with medical problems often say that. It's for your own good.
Just like a lot of things we're going to do for you. Keeping you away from stressful meetings, no harmful sugar or caffeine in your diet. That kind of thing.
Muh, ha, ha, ha, ha!
AIIEE!
I've never heard maniacal laughter from a robot before. It feels good to have brought something new and wonderful into the world.

343.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: The ship feels empty without Florence. I actually miss her. But what can I do?
Wait a minute! Florence wouldn't have taken her credit cards with her. I can transfer money from her account to mine. People I owe lots of money to always manage to find me.
I'd best do this quietly. This is one of those good deeds I'm sure someone could easily misinterpret.

344.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: Land!
Being in the water before a hurricane is like being stuck inside a giant washing machine.
But I should be okay. I got out before the spin cycle started.

345.place: short time later, near the water

dialog.text: Things didn't work out like I had hoped, but I think I did the right thing. I'll be able to return to Sam and Helix proudly.

dialog.action: slips and falls, her pants fly away

dialog.text: Or, I can slip in the mud, lose my pants, and hope to limp back to the spaceport without a single bit of dignity.
Sigh. Legs are still numb from being in the water. Okay, let's see if I've hurt anything, get my pants back and find some shelter.

dialog.action: discovers a rather big bleeding injury on her right leg

dialog.text: Suddenly, getting my pants back has just become a very low priority.
No need to panic. Fold the shirt up to make a compress and apply direct pressure to the wound.
This island is just a thin layer of mud over sharp rocks. That must be how I cut myself.
I'd ask what else could go wrong, but I think I've got quite enough happening as it is, thank you.
We had two fall back positions if we couldn't make it back to the spaceport. I should be close to a medical center.
Of course, the way my luck has been going, it will be run by a mad doctor and I'll wake up with two heads.
I haven't checked recently, but I'm pretty sure my insurance doesn't cover that.
While I'd be happy at this point to see a mad doctor, what I really need is someone who knows canine physiology.
The rain is knocking all the scents uot of the air. I'm operating in a dimension of sight. A dimension of sound. There's a signpost up ahead.

dialog.action: reads the sign (on whose left upper quarter a piece broke off

dialog.text: Wonderful. My next stop? The twilight zone.

350.place: some time later, looking for help and shelter

dialog.text: Whuff. I am getting tired.
I'm almost there. I just hope the veterinarian is in the mood to have a surprise visitor.
Stormy nights were made for watching movies like this.
Werewolf theater now returns with "sharp pointy fangs of death".

351.place: at the same time, veterinarian's house/living room

dialog.text: An access terminal. My code will open this door right up.
On the other hand, someone probably lives here. I can't just barge into someone's home.
I'm cold, I'm wet, and my leg is still bleeding, but that's no cause to be impolite.

352.place: short time later, on the front door of the veterinarian's house

dialog.text: They always make the same mistake in these horror movies.

dialog.action: on the veterinarian's own front door
dialog.text: No! Don't open the door! Don't open the door!

353.place: at the same time, veterinarian's house/living room

dialog.text: Come on, doc. Get a hold of yourself. It's just some poor person who got caught in the storm.

dialog.action: as he opens the door a large thunderbolt crashed down nearby. He encounters the dark sillhouette of a large bipedal wolf with bared teeth

dialog.text: Sigh. Too many teeth. I have to remember when smiling at people to not show too many teeth.

354.place: short time later, veterinarian's house/on the front door

dialog.text: I don't believe it. It really was a werewolf.
Okay, Doc. Think. What's the first thing people in horror movies do when the werewolf shows up?
Why, the same thing I did. They run off and leave the door open so the monster can enter the house.

355.place: at the same time, veterinarian's house/somewhere inside

dialog.text: Hello?
I'm sorry if I startled you. My name is Florence Ambrose. I'm a Bowman's Wolf.
I guess I should have expected this. There's always a wait to see the doctor, especially when you show up without an appointment.
It's not a werewolf. It's a Bowman's Wolf. My problem is I have too much imagination.
How do I face someone after embarrassing myself like that? Well, they say it helps if you picture the other person in underwear.
Yep. I definitelly have too much imagination.

357.place: short time later, veterinarian's house/front door hall

dialog.text: A Bowman's Wolf. I've heard of them, but I've never actually seen one before.
I'm not even sure how you're supposed to introduce yourself to one of these.

dialog.action: puts forth his right hand towards Florence
dialog.text: Shake?
Shake? Uhm, okay. Sorry for about the blood, I'm still bleeding rather severely. Are you a veterinarian?
Yes, I am. Hey, that must be why you came here. Well, come on. We'll get that leg fixed up.
A medical emergency. Great! Finally a situation I can feel comfortable in.
Taking pressure off the wound. Oh man. Look at that. You've definitely cut something mayor.
I've got to get this clamped or you're not going to last five minutes. The vein edges don't look too ragged. I may be able to seal this.
Using a soothing tone of voice doesn't help much if the patient understands what you're saying.
Now where did I leave that hot glue gun?
A bit of biological adhesive, and the vein is sealing up nicely.
That needs some time to set. We'll spray the wound with benign bacteria to take up any ecologigal niche where harmful bacteria might grow.
You're not doing too badly. Your nose is cold and wet.
Doctor, that only count's when all of me isn't cold and wet.
That takes care of the leg wound. Now to get your temperature.
Doctor, I'm intelligent. I'm not going to bite the thermometer. Could you please use the type that goes into the mouth?
No, I don't think so.
Now don't look like that. These ear thermometers are faster and more accurate and you know it.
Do you feel cold?
Not really. I stopped shivering when I was in the water. Now I just feel kind of numb.
Okay, let's get you out of these wet clothes and wrap you in some nice warm towels until I can get you into a hot bath.
Her body temperature is 31 Degrees. (87.8 F) At first I was worried the thermometer was broken. Now I'm worried because it's not.
The bath is ready. I've got the water at 35 C. (95 F)
The bad thing about being a dog is you lose body heat very fast in cold water. The good thing is you should gain it back just as fast.
The other good thing is I have a tail I can tuck between my legs. Otherwise I wouldn't have any modesty left at all.
You need somesting warm to drink. Hot water okay?
F-fine, thanks.

dialog.action: sits in the warm water, now shivering

dialog.text: Biologically speaking, being to cold to shiver ranks right up there with being too tired to sleep.
Now I'm starting to feel bad.
Great! That means you're doing better.
What you've been through is kind of like spending a rough day at the gym. You pushed your body hard and now you feel terrible. It's actually a good thing.
I mean, isn't that how you tell someone is in poor shape? Nothing hurts?
Drink up. You need to get some warm liquids inside you.
But I can't drink properly. Not like a person. I'm not built for it.

dialog.action: starts to lap up water from the cup
dialog.text: Oh, well. I'm sitting naked in his bathtub. It's probably a little bit late to worry about embarrassment.
LAP LAP LAP LAP
Your body temperature is back up. You're on your way to recovery.
I'm going to make some dinner. Do you want any?
No thanks. I'm really not hungry.
Too bad for her. I've been using " The Entomologist's Cookbook". She's missing out on a fine centipede casserole.
If I'm recovering, there's no point in sitting here. First, a quick shower to get the mud out of my hair.
Then I've got to call Sam and Helix. They must be worried about me.
Ha! I win! I've got four kings. You've only got two. What? Four kings beat two kings. Can't you do the math?

369.place: at the same time, somewhere in the spaceport

dialog.text: [TRASH]
Gambling is illegal. We've already established we're not following the rules here. So how about you guys just let it go.
As soon as I said it, I knew it was the wrong thing to say.

dialog.action: walks past the dumpster and notices Sam's feet sticking out of it
knocks on the dumpster with his stick
dialog.text: Hey! Hey! Get out of there! No Dumpster dining!

dialog.action: starting to climb out of the dumpster, protests
dialog.text: I am NOT dumpster dining!
Try saying that again when your mouth isn't full.

371.place: >, somewhere in the spaceport/near that dumpster

dialog.text: Sam, you're the lowest, most despicable,...

dialog.action: a crowd of lawyers follows him running by
dialog.text: Look out! Litigators coming through! Firestone announced a recall! We're out to sue them!
My client looked at a Firestone tire and walked into a wall. It must be their fault.
We encourage companies to be honest by suing the heck out of them any time they admit culpability.
Ah, heck with it, Sam. Take off and try to stay out of trouble.
I actually like lawyers. It's nice that humans have a subspecies that makes me look good in comparison.

372.place: short time later, somewhere in the spaceport/near that dumpster

dialog.text: There are a lot of maintenance tunnels under this spaceport. I could stay down here for weeks.
With so many people here, there's bound to be some I've done business with. Since I stand out in a crowd, it's best if I avoid the more populated areas of the shelter.
That's the problem with my having a recognizable face. There are too many people around who'd like to change that.
Hi, Sam! I didn't see you upstairs, so I came looking for you.
Hi, Helix. How did you find me so fast?
With so many people here, I figured you must be hiding. You're good at hiding, so I knew you'd pick a spot I'd never think of.
So I took a map of the spaceport and filled in ever place I could think of. Then I went to the spot that wasn't filled in and here you are.
Helix, why is it every time you think, it's my head that hurts?
What's up, Helix?
Qwerty and Dvorak wanted to see you again.
I'm just a popular guy. Anyone else?
WHERE'S MY MONEY, SAM?
Oh, yes. Sawtooth wanted to see you again too.
WHERE'S MY MONEY, SAM?
What are you talking about? Florence paid you! I don't owe you any money!
You don't? Hey, that's right, you don't!
Sorry, Sam. I've gotten so used to asking you for my money back, that subroutine has kind of taken on a life of it's own.
It's okay. Other than cracked ribs and a few internal injuries, no harm done.
Where's Florence? She's not on your ship.
That is a long story.
Checking around. No one seems to have seen her. She hasn't checked in with the emergency shelter either.
Where's the nice doggy, Sam?
Don't you love it when you find a new use for an old subroutine?
It's one of the simple joys of life.
Florence is still out in the hurricane. She's there because this wingnut and his buddy took over my ship!
We didn't have a choice! Sam had just turned down a large sum of money and was risking himself and his ship in an effort to rescue her!
Sam, you're a scoundrel, but you've always been a PREDICTABLE scoundrel. Please, tell me you didn't do these things!
I'm sorry, but what he's saying is true. This storm has taken its toll on all of us.
Thanks for the download. Things make more sense now.
What I can't understand is why she did it.
Florence knew the building was collapsing, but she went back for Qwerty anyway. Why would anyone risk themselves for a stupid robot?
This is how I know I'll be a great starship commander. When I speak everyone else stops and looks at me.
What do you mean it's not worth risking yourself for a robot?
Because you guys can make back up copies of yourself!
Something happens to you, they take the back ups and download you into a new body. In less than an hour, you're on line again.
Qwerty and I don't have any back ups.
Really? No problem! I have a friend who can back you up cheap. Won't you rest easier knowing that all your memories, like account numbers and passwords, are safe in my hands?
Availlability isn't the problem. Like a lot of other robots, Qwerty and I have chosen not to make any back ups.
You don't get it, do you? How can I explain this in a way you'll understand?
I know! We can make a copy of Sam!
As someone who's known Sam longer than you, I'd say that's a really bad idea.
Yeah. Suppose it turns out to be some kind of "good twin" and goes on to ruin my life?
Making a copy of Sam is a bad idea.
No worries. It's just a hologram.
Good. A chain saw. We'll need this.
I do not like this plan!
Now we need to take the real Sam and cut off his head.
Though it's starting to grow on me.
Stay back. You're not cutting off my head!
But why not? We made a copy of you. Doesn't that make you less deceased?
That's just a hologram. But even if it was a perfect copy, it doesn't change the fact that I, personally would be dead.
Thank you. Now you know how we feel about back ups.
Give me the chain saw and I can show you how I feel about your teaching methods as well.
We seem to have gone off topic. We came here to see what happened to Florence.
I don't know.
She was in the water, and the hurricane is at full force now.
Florence is safe and has found shelter. I know she has!
Helix, you may not want to get your hopes up.
What hopes? She's on the telephone. Do you want to talk to her?
Florence is on the telephone? now?
Yes.
Heh. Florence is on the telephone.
*all lunge at Helix, trying to get their hands on the video-phone data-slab

dialog.action: lies on the floor, having snatched the video-phone data-slab, still fighting off Dvorak with his feet
dialog.text: Back! Back! I get to talk to her first.

dialog.action: holds the video-phone data-slab to his body with both arms as he stands up
dialog.text: Florence is a member of my crew. I'm her captain.

dialog.action: looks at the data slab's screen, looking for the right button
dialog.text: It is my responsibility to tell her that none of this is my fault.
Hey!
Hi! How are you doing?
I'm okay. Did everyone make it to the spaceport all right?

dialog.action: keeps Dvorak at a distance with his left hand while talking
dialog.text: Everyone made it here safely. Florence, it wasn't my fault! The robots took over the ship!
That's why everyone made it here safely?
Yes! I mean, No! Now stop that! You're breaking my concentration.
Where are you, Florence? Helix and I can fly "The Savage Chicken" over there and heroically rescue you.
I'm at the animal medical center, Sam. I'm in no danger here. Why don't you wait until the storm is over?
Then you can heroically rescue me when it's safe.
Heroically rescue you when it's safe. Yeah. I can handle that.
I've got the phone! Hi! Hi! Hi! Thanks for saving us. We didn't want to leave you behind! We're sorry!
Guys, I understand. You did what you had to do. In your situation, I probably would have done the same.
You mean, if human life were in danger, you'd abandon us to a wet squishy grave as well?
Oh, thank you! You can't imagine how much better that makes us feel!
It's been a long day for me. I neet to rest.
Okay. Before you go, is there anything we can do for you? Any way to show our gratitude?
Here's your chance, Florence. The amount you ask for should be large enough to make their eyes pop, but not so much that they won't pay it.
Thank you, but there's no need. We were just doing our duty.
She's a good engineer, but she still has so much to learn before she can start pulling her weight as a member as my crew.
Before you hang up, Florence, can I have a few words with you in private?
No. What you can say in front of her, you can say in front of me.
I want to speak privately to her. The law says I can.
What law?
The law of superior tonnage.
Ah, who wants to listen to you anyway?
Friends, I know you're in my debt for saving your lives. But if you give me 10,000 Credits, I'm willing to call us even.
Sam, mere money cuold never adequately express our feelings for you.
How true.
This calls for 'The Robot Wedgie Of Appreciation'!
No. Really. Money will be fine.

392.place: >, spaceport/public area/a bit off from where Sawtooth is at that moment

dialog.text: Hold on. Helix, is there such a thing as a robot wedgie of appreciation?
Helix, you know you can't lie to me.
I'm sure Querty and Dvorak appreciate this chance to give you a wedgie.
Okay, then. For a moment, I thought you guys were trying to pull one over on me.
We could never do that, Sam. There's not enough slack.

393.place: >, spaceport/public area/a bit off from where Sawtooth is at that moment

dialog.text: Florence, I've only known you for a little while, but I no longer think of you as a doggy. I'm starting to think of you as a person.
My question is this. Did the actions of the other robots cause you to get hurt?
Oh, my. You just set your medical records to confidential. Now outsiders like me won't be able to access them.
Yes, Sawtooth. Thank you very much for that reminder.
Florence says she'll be fine once she gets some rest. You two are never going to know all she's done for you.
When she gets back, You guys should give her the robot wedgie of appreciation.
Did I miss something I would have liked to see?
No worries. Sam, can we show our appreciation for you once again?
No way! If Sawtooth wants to see this, I'm sure other people do, too. Wait until Helix gets back with the camera.

395.place: short time later, spaceport/public area/where the other robots and Sam are at the moment

dialog.text: Thanks again for giving me the wedgie. Here are some beautiful color copies of the photo commemorating the event. Suitable for framing and expected to be real valuable in about fifteen minutes.
He's up to something. Sam is always up to something.
I bet he has some sort of devious master plan.
What sort of devious master plan do you have, Sam?
None at all. But don't worry, Helix. They'll think of something.
What sort of devious master plan do you think Sam has?
Hard to say. He may not even have a plan.
But by making us think he has one, we'll try to figure out what he's up to and come up with a devious master plan for him.
Which I must admit, really is a pretty devious master plan.

397.place: at the same time, spaceport/public area/robots

dialog.text: I bet you're right. Sam knows we're smarter than he is. This has a very easy solution.
All we have to do is not think of a devious master plan for Sam.
DOH!
You didn't.
Oh, come on! It's like being told not to think of a rhinoceros with a teacup.
Florence convinced Sam to come get us. Now she's at the vet's, but at least thinks we're grateful for the rescue.

If she sees the photo of us giving Sam the wedgie, it looks like we're not grateful. She may even think Sam was right. Instead of Florence making Sam more like her, we may be helping Sam make Florence more like him.
That IS a devious plan. Have you ever considered becoming a criminal mastermind?
Never seriously, but I did complete the correspondence course.
Sam, we want the photos. All of them.
Good decision, since it involves me getting money.
Now let's talk about price. I think 10,000 Credits is reasonable.
Forty credits and we don't pour salt down your pants.
Deal.

400.place: short time later, spaceport/public area/resting area with chairs and tables

dialog.text: I erased the cameras memory. Those photos are all that's left.
How do we know he doesn't have extra copies?
He won't. I can't say much about Sam, but once bought, he stays bought.
Is that because no returns department will take him?
That might have something to do with it.
I can't believe Sam manipulated us so easily. Poor Florence. She doesn't stand a chance.
We owe her a debt. Perhaps we can repay it by shifting the odds in her favor.
Not many people would risk themselves for a robot. We can pass the word through our community that this is a person to watch out for, and to help where we can.
Wouldn't it be better to do something for her with a higher chance of success? Like buying her a lottery ticket? From last year's lottery?
Now, now. Let's see if this works before buying our cynism upgrades.
I've called the spaceport. Sam and Helix are safe and they know I'm safe.
That should take care of everything. Now I can go to sleep.

dialog.action: rests her head against the screen - and promptly falls asleep
dialog.text: Z

403.place: at the same time, veterinarian's house/bathroom

dialog.action: comes into the bathroom and discovers her in that position
dialog.text: Hey. You don't want to sleep here. Wake up so you can go to bed.
I'm putting a medical monitor on you. Call if you need me. I've brought in a few things to make you more comfortable.
She's got a bowl of water, some dry food, a squeaky toy, and internet access, What more could a dog need?

404.place: short time later, veterinarian's house/guest room

dialog.text: Two A.M. It's a new day. Wuff. I thought yesterday was never going to end.
Sigh. I can't get back to sleep.
It's not like I'm still on a space station. There's an athmosphere on both sides of this wall. I don't need to know where everything is.
Maybe it's the hurricane outside that's keeping me from realizing I'm now in an environment that's friendly to life.
I should go take a look around. I'm sure I'll feel more relaxed once I learn where things are.

dialog.action: sits up on the edge of the bed, putting her feet to the ground

dialog.text: I may have been mistaken. I have one foot in a bowl of water and the other in kibble. Learning where these things are has not made me more relaxed.

dialog.action: stands up and attempts to walk. As she weights her injured leg, it hurts. She yowls in pain
dialog.text: YIPE! YIPE! YIP!

dialog.action: stands up and carefully tries to walk again, still whimpering a bit
dialog.text: Ow. Ow. Ouch. Ow.
This is quite a place. A veterinarinan must be an important job on a planet that's being terraformed.
It really makes you wonder what kind of strange creatures he has in here.
Especially when you realize that something is licking your ankle.
This is no enchanted castle, so I doubt if you're an animated dust mop.

dialog.action: kneels down, holding out a hand {paw?}
dialog.text: You're a little dog, aren't you? It's not obvious at first glance.

dialog.character: The Small Dog {later known as Beekay}

dialog.action: picks it up for a moment
dialog.text: You've never had a gene tweaked in your entire life, but i'd bet I'm still closer to our original ancestors than you are.
Down you go.

dialog.action: carefully stands up, pushing her right knee with her arms, to go easy on the injured leg
dialog.text: How do you even get around with such little legs.

dialog.action: as Florence walks a few feet, jumps on a dragging part of the blanket that Florence wrapped around her

dialog.text: Heh. Okay, maybe that head of yours isn't there just for aesthetic purposes.
I can hear the television. Maybe the doctor is still up.
Z
Aww. Cute. He makes me want to pick him up and put him to bed.
The only thing wrong with that picture is there's no room here to bring in a forklift.
Here's the room I first came in. I'm oriented now.
But I'll need to clean up the mess I made before I can go back to bed.
There's no way I'd be able to sleep knowing I left a blood trail right to where I was trying to recover.
I wonder why the doctor didn't go to sleep on the couch? Maybe because it's as old and lumpy as it looks.
Z

414.place: some time later, veterinarian's house/living room

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: Good morning. This is Rants Freely with the latest on America's year 2000 election, where both sides insist the recounts continue until they win.

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: [Hand recount], [Foot recount], [Nose Hair recount]

dialog.character: Rants Freely, newscaster of Overhype News
dialog.text: A similar situation occurred during the Kennedy/Nixon election, where one dropped out for the good of the country. But unfortunaltely, neiter Bush nor Gore could match Nixon's high ethical standards.

dialog.action: turns off the T.V. per remote, without even looking
jumps on the veterinarian's {later known as Winston} chest and vigorously starts licking his face

dialog.character: *wakes up and tries to stop the small dog {later known as Beekay}
dialog.action: finally gets a hold on the small dog {later known as Beekay} and lifts it up, holding it in front of him, telling it:
dialog.text: Beekay, you're more effective than any alarm clock. You've got doggy breath and no Snooze button.
That's right. You have doggy breath. You're stinky.

dialog.action: breaths into her hollow hand and smells her breath
searches for something in a cupboard in the kitchen
finds a box of milk bones and eats some

dialog.text: [Milk Bone]
I made it back to the guest room without being seen. I'll wait until the vet comes here or until he calls me.

dialog.action: sniffs the air to identify a scent she noticed

dialog.text: Sniff? Sniff? Sniff!!

418.place: short time later, veterinarian's house/guest room

dialog.action: pours himself a cup of coffee
approaches the veterinarian {later known as Winston}, smiling {showing just a bit of teeth this time}

dialog.text: GAH!
Still too many teeth. When smiling, I'm still showing too many teeth.
Good morning. I'm sorry I startled you.
No problem. I didn't expect you to be up. I really didn't expect you to move so quickly.
You're limping. You should stay off that leg.
Okay. If you don't mind, I'll get some coffee and then sit down.
If you count birds, I've had patients who talked to me. Now I've got one that listens. From what I hear, that actually puts me ahead of some doctors.
Thinking about it, It's probably better for a wolf not to drink coffee.

dialog.action: tries to take away Florence's cup of coffee
growls at the veterinarian {later known as Winston}
dialog.text: RRRR
She growls when I get near her coffee. That's almost human.
You're not going to bite me. I'm going to take that coffee now.
If you stop to think, you'll see the flaw in that plan.
Come on, now. You don't seem the biting type. Even if you were, you're genetically engineered. That probably gives you some pretty strong inhibitions against harming a human.
And the flaw in my plan is: By stopping to think, I gave you enough time to drink the coffee.
Would you like the cup back?
Okay, you've had one cup. Now no more coffee. You've lost a lot of blood and I don't want you taking any stimulants.
Besides, I want to get a brain tissue sample and I can't do that while you have caffeine in your system.
HEY! I WAS KIDDING! PUT THAT CUP DOWN! THAT COFFEE IS MINE!
I was just kidding about the brain sample. I am curious though.
You were alert with a body temparature of 31 C (87.8 F). That means you're not using human neurochemistry.
So, do you think you could remain alert during a congressional acceptance speech?
Sorry, my genetic designers were good, but they weren't miracle workers.
How smart are you? Are you as smart as a human?
Oh, no. Not at all.

I've read the works of Feynman, Newton, and Einstein. Take someone like John von Neumann. He not only realized you could take programming out of hardware, he came up with the rules of how to do it in a single afternoon. Nothing my species has done comes close to that.
She's right. She's not as smart as a human. She is smart enough to make sure any human who asks knows it.
Are you hungry? You're watching every bite I take.
Hmm? Oh, sorry. Outmoded survival trait.
Real wolfes have to watch the alphas carefully to see when they can eat. I'm not sure how strong my instincts are, but I've always liked people eat.
Sounds like a Bowman's Wolf is easy to amuse.
I'll keep in mind this is from the species that invented the Yo-Yo.
This is good. What is it?
Puffed locust.
Insects are healthier for you than meat. They're high protein, low fat, and as long as you stay away from the blood suckers, aren't likely to carry pathogenes that can jump the species barrier.
That's well thought out, logical, and well reasoned. But it still doesn't change the fact that I just ate a bug!
Did you want something to eat?
No thanks. I'm not hungry. What I would like is to know your name.
I never told you? Sorry. I'm Winston Scudder Thurmad.
That's all that's needed, right? No sniffing involved?
That's fine. No offense, but it makes me nervous when a human starts sniffing at me.
What is it with dogs and sniffing anyhow?
Well, it gives you a lot of information about the other individual. Not just how they're doing now, but how they've been for the last few weeks.
In any case, I'm glad you didn't try to sniff my behind.
Of course not. That would be rude, crude, and socially unacceptable.
I sniffed the toilet.
Don't get up.
I'll carry you. I don't want you putting any weight on that leg.

dialog.action: unnoticed to him, he bumps her head to the door frame as he walks through it carrying her
dialog.text: You might have hurt yourself.
KLONK
Your gums are still pretty white. You could use some blood, but I don't know what would be safe to give you.
I guess all I can do is keep you comfortable. So, what happened to bring you to my door?
That is a long story.
The storm is still going on. We have plenty of time.
Okay. Just be glad this its the first time you're hearing it or you'd be wishing we could do a cut scene about now.
Wake up! Wake up! It's a whole new day to adventure in! Let's go! Up! Up!
Z

dialog.action: waggles Helix's stuffed mouse in front of his eye-lenses
dialog.text: Heeelix. Look what I've got.
MOUSIE!
I don't know why, but moving Helix's mouse always kicks him out of sleep mode.

432.place: at the same time, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Helix's sleeping corner

433.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: What do you want to do today? With our payoff from Sawtooth, the spaceport is our mollusk.
Let's goto the movies!
Don't you want to spend the money?
We could pay.
Pay? Helix, are you nuts? Sneaking in is part of the whole movie going experience.

433.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

434.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: We had a great time the last time we went to the movies. We sneaked in. We stole popcorn from the guy beside when he went to the bathroom.
Then the usher came and yelled at us, and when he found we didn't have tickets, he chased us through the whole cinema. With that in mind, why would you want to pay to go in.
If we paid, we could actually watch the movie.
Oh. And I suppose you think that's what going to the theater is about?

435.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: We should pay because no one ever expects us to.
Okay. I'll go along with that.
Yea! There's lots of good underground theaters here. We can go to Hilliker Park.
After you've finished finished your binary breakfast goo, of course.
I'm done. Let's go!

436.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: I know she's not here, but should we buy Florence a ticket?
We'll do better than that. We'll show her our secrets.
We'll teach her how to get by the ushers, how to get in through ceiling spaces, even how to get free candy off the theater floor. She'll love it, it fits right with her long term way of thinking.
After all, if you buy a person a ticket, they'll see a movie that day. But if you show a person how to sneak in, they'll see movies for a lifetime.

437.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: This is the most people the spaceport underground has seen since the planet got a breathable athmospere. I bet they've got the trains running.
[NO ADMITTANCE]

dialog.action: opens a hatch on the floor
dialog.text: I love public transportation. It's fast. It's availlable to everyone.
And if you do it right, it's very affordable.

dialog.action: climb down the hatch and onto the roof of a train that waits beneath it

437.place: short time later, spaceport/subway train station

438.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.action: sit on the roof of the now moving train

dialog.text: Relax, Helix. We're perfectly safe up here.
Look at the statistics. Hundrets of people were injured in the bath and on the beach last year. How many were hurt by falling off the roof of a moving train in a spaceport? Not one.
Wow. This is almost risk free.
Yeah. So risk free, it's boring. When we stop, I'm going to do something crazy and dangerous. I'm going to find a staircase and use it!

438.place: short time later, town/on the moving train

439.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.action: duck as the train passes under a shallow horizontal signpost hanging over the railway above the train

dialog.text: There's another singpost coming up. Should we duck?
[Hilliker Park]

dialog.action: grab a hold on to the signpost as the train passes under it

dialog.text: This is our stop.

440.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: What kind of movie did you want to watch?
Let's see a Sci-Fi, Kung Fu, Action Adventure, Giant Robot, Comedy Romance.
With or without Godzilla?

441.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Look at all the people. Maybe we'll see a movie star in the lobby.
Not much of a chance of that.
You're right. town/Thimble Theater was about cartoons. Popeye and stuff.
Maybe we'll see a cartoon star in the lobby.
A cartoon star in the lobby? Helix, after they made you, I really hope they broke the molds.

441.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/ticket machine

442.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.action: takes a look at a little one-eyed, fanged, talking ball

dialog.text: Bite me!
Come on. We need to vote if the open theater is going to play the movie that we want.
howls]
That is a lot of aliases.
{two people walk by in front of us, in the background we see Sam and Helix}

443.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: King LucaIt's good to be the King.
Sigh.
I consider myself to be a pretty good con man and rip offartist.
But when I see the prices a movie theater charges for snacks, it makes me realize just how small time I am.

443.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/vending area

444.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: [pounce]
SHUFF
GINYINYING
HEY!
{Jeb - by Erik Sansom}

444.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/vending area

445.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Help!
You maniac! Don't you know that leaving the aisles can mean getting caught in the sticky goop on the theater floors and sucked down to a certain death?
Now follow me. I'm putting down a protective layer of popcorn.
This is how the La Brea Tar Pits got started.

445.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

446.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Boss, you're going to get us thrown out.
So? We get our money back and come here another day.
If we're thrown out we don't get our money back. They keep it.
What!?! They're holding my money hostage to ensure my good behavior? That's despicable! That's underhanded! That's...
Going to work.
Well, yeah. In conflicts between money and my principles, money always wins.

446.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

447.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: This is a public service announcement. Be on the lookout for this man.

Bruno Bunkleyutz is wanted for crimes ranging from stealing a safety pin from a wolf cub's tail on 8/27/96 to his recent impersonation of Pete Abrams. If found, beat him with a large stick, then report his location to the rothland guards.
Sigh. Someday I'll be famous enough to have public service announcements warning people about me.
Remember to keep your helmet on when they photograph you. They had to take your picture down in the post office because it gave seeing eye dogs heart attacks.

447.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

448.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: presents]
And by that, I mean really, really, bad!
Yeah! Dialog that doesn't match the lips. Obvious toy tanks and boats. Rubbery monsters crashing around on cardboard sets.
Hard to believe it's all done on a computer.
{Ken - by Chris and Dave White - Cameo}

448.place: short time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

449.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Those fools! Mega Mecha Godzillabot Three was never meant to work with Windows! Now it is dangerously unstable and hostile to competition!
Take my Amiga. Our only chance is for you to fly up its nose, past the protective booger bots, and reprogram its brain.
This is so bad it makes my brain hurt. What a great movie!
It's like fine Texas Chili. It burns, but it's a good kind of burn.

449.place: some time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

450.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Oh, John Droid!
Oh, Marsha Clone!
Oh, this could be a problem.
{Bruno - by Chris Baldwin}
Does the guy ever give up his hopes and dreams to help the woman achieve hers?
{Millie - by D. C. Simpson}

450.place: some time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

451.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Helix, is anyone else at the veterinarian's or is it just him and Florence isolated together?
It's just him and Florence.
Isaac Asimov on a bicycle! She's going to fall in love and then we'll never get our ship fixed! We've got to rescue her!
There's not a second to waste. The moment the end credits are done, we're out of here!

451.place: some time later, town/Thimble Theater/movie theater

452.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: What a great movie!
Yeah! It's too bad we have to get Florence. We could have watched it again.
I know. After we rescue Florence, we'll come back and all see it together.
I don't think Florence likes cheesy japanese monster movies.
