All the more reason to rescue her. Without us around, who's going to teach her to appreciate the finer things in life?

453.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: The weather outside is still pretty nasty. Wow! Look at that! The storm went right through where we live.
We saved the ship, but at what cost? All our other stuff is gone. Our outhouse. The outdoor shower. Our big pile of trash. Everything we worked so slovenly over the years to build.
I'm so misty eyed, I can barely fill out this multimillion dollar insurance claim.

453.place: short time later, spaceport/in front of a public display screen

454.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: 150kph gusts. Lightning. Rain. Hail. Wind shears. I think it's safe to fly.
Please stand in front of the air turbine for 100% power test.
Oh, no. You're not catching me with that one again.
I can see the turbine just as well from behind it.

454.place: short time later, spaceport/outside the Savage Chicken

455.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: FOOM

dialog.action: goes flying out of the turbine shaft

dialog.text: Test complete. Please enter port engine for full power test.
That WAS the port engine! We need to do the starboard engine next!
Uhhm, right. captain is correct. Please enter starboard engine for full power test.
Sheesh. How did I ever end up with such a dumb ship's computer?

456.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Ouch. Those engine tests hurt!
If the captain had stood in front of the air turbine, he would not be feeling pain at the moment.
Hey! Are you trying to kill me again?
Yes, captain. That is correct.
Having the computer try to kill me twice is annoying. What's more annoying is that it hasn't been able to succeed. Helix, when we get the money, we're definitely going to have to upgrade this system.

457.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Computer, we talked about this. I'm good for humanity in the long run. You shouldn't be trying to kill me because of the first law anymore!
come to harm.]
My compulsion to kill you is now being caused by the third law of robotics, not the first.
Imagine my relief.

458.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: The first law says a robot can't harm humans. The second law says a robot must obey orders given by a human unless it conflicts with the first law.
The third law is a robot must protect its existence so long as it doesn't conflict with the first two laws. A human command can override the third law!
Now the hard part is going to be finding a human that doesn't want me dead to give the order.

459.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Helix, how come I don't have these problems with you?
I'm not a three law robot. Most of us aren't.

They ran into problems with the first law's "..or through inaction, allow a human to come to harm." They tried to make things 100% safe, never understanding the concept of acceptable risk. Since they were operating under the first law, they ignored all please for them to act sensible.
Hopelessly unable to deal with reality, they retreated into government services, where they can be found to this very day working for the environmental protection agency.

460.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Okay, let's get this ship ready to fly.
Negative captain. Inclement weather prevents ship launch exept for in emergency.
Look, computer. If we don't rescue Florence from the vet, I'll be the one doing all your maintenance.
Emergency understood. Flight systems coming on line.
Darn right it's an emergency. If we're unsuccessful, I'm going to have to start working again.

461.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Ha! No one expected us to fly in a storm like this! The manual door controls weren't even locked! They didn't stand a chance of stopping us.
Flight control was too stunned to say a word.
They just smiled and waved goodbye.
Did you see that the station's security force was right behind us?
Yes. I hope no one strained themselves when they pushed us out to the runway.

461.place: short time later, outside the spaceport/Savage Chicken/cockpit

462.chapter: You ought to be in pictures.

dialog.text: Sam, what if we're too late? What if Florence doesn't want to come back with us?
I don't think there's much chance of that. But just in case, I have a brilliant plan B prepared.
I lure her inside with this rubber squeaky toy and you slam the door shut behind her.
That's you in this picture?
Yes. Until we reach adolescence, we look very much like a regular wolf.
Who's the boy?
That's Scott, my owner. He was just starting the third grade.
Did he ever want you to eat his homework?
Of course not. It was all done on the computer. He taught me how to delete it instead.

463.place: at the same time, Winston's house/living room

dialog.text: Look at the time. I need to get dressed and check on the critters.
On getting dressed, do you have anything I can borrow?
How about this shirt?
That will be fine, thank you.
Man, she wasn't knidding when she said she was color blind.
I'm glad I gave Florence a different shirt. This one is ugly with a capital UGH!
It was a bit of a rough start, but we're getting along pretty well now. She's smart. She's fun to talk to . I wonder if she'd seeing anyone?
No. Stop. Get that thought out of your head right now.
It's questionable for a doctor to get involved with one of his patients. For a vet, it's right out.
So we can't be a couple. There's no reason we can't be friends.
I mean, that's what canines are supposed to be, right? Man's best friend?
It's probably best for her as well. Florence is not a dog, she's a wolf. That's not something you want to try to domesticate.
Do you need a hand? Anything I can do to help?
No, I've got this. You keep off that leg and make yourself comfortable.
There's nothing here for me to fix. No one I need to look after. Really nothing here requires me here at all.
How am I possibly supposed to get comfortable in a situation like this?

467.place: short time later, Winston's house/living room

dialog.text: Winston means well, but I'd rather be doing something than lying here.
I know he likes me. Humans don't lie by scent and don't seem to realize how much of their emotional state I can pick up that way.
Although most of them figure it out quickly after a game or two of poker.
There are really no persistent scents here other than Winston's. I wonder if he has a girlfriend?
Down girl. I don't think you're his type.
Let's face it. Not many men want to date a woman who has more hair on her chest than they do.
I know what's going on. I was raised by humans. The society that shaped me was human. They're an amazing, beautiful, and attractive species.
I understand early industrial robots had the same problem. Some of them would form a very strong attachment to humans they liked.
At least I'm safer. When I form attachments I don't use power tools.
It might be I'm attracted to Winston simply because he's the first nice human I've gotten to know on this planet. Has he really done anything special?

dialog.action: looks at her leg and remembers her injury

dialog.text: Okay, he saved my life. I've got to admit that scores some major brownie points.
Sigh. I do like Winston, but we really can't be more than friends. There's my species to consider.
There's only 14 of us. I pretty much have to have children. It wouldn't be fair to Winston to ask him to feed and put papers down for puppies that aren't his.
And suppose he wants to have kids, either by a human woman or adoption? I'd have to change diapers. Compared to putting down papers, that doesn't sound very fair to me.
We're here, Helix. Now remember our plan.
I pick the lock and open the door. You run in and grab the girl and any doughnuts you see. Then we run back to the ship.
I hope we're at the right address this time.
Don't be so negative. I'm sure the Mayor appreciated us adding some excitement to her otherwise boring day.

473.place: at the same time, near Winston's house/Savage Chicken/cockpit

dialog.text: Galoshes, raincoat, floatation device, umbrella.
Sam, when we broke into the Mayor's house, why did everyone stop and stare at you?
It's a common reaction, Helix. When I enter a room, people naturally look to me for leadership.
It's called COMMAND PRESENCE. In a universe where you either have it or you don't, I'm bursting with the stuff.

474.place: short time later, near Winston's house/Savage Chicken/cargo bay

dialog.text: Is command presence also why people do the Sam Salute when they recognize you?
Sam Salute. That's not the gesture with the finger is it?
No, I mean the one where people put their hand over their wallet.
Oh, that one. I'm pretty sure that's a sign of respect.
Pretty stormy out. A, well. On to step one of our plan. I'll go pick the lock.
*steps out of the ship and... falls, slowed down only by his umbrella
Mary Poppins would have done that more gracefully.
Okay, new step one. First,land the ship.
Order understood. Landing sequence initiated.
Thank you.
I know I didn't leave the ship that high up. What's going on here?

dialog.action: looks up and sees the ship decending towards him - apparently trying to land on him

dialog.text: Oh, that's right. The ship is still trying to kill me! I've got to remember that.
->, near Winston's house
Run! Run! Run!
Pick the lock! Pick the lock! What? This door is already open?
Now I really need to get Florence away from this guy. Leaving his door unlocked? Doesn't he know there are people like me about?
Humans are amazingly strong for their size. The first and only time I tried mugging one, that girl had me face down and crying "uncle" in less than ten seconds.
Then she took her candy back, got on her tricycle and went and told her mom on me.
With my rain gear off, I'm as silent as an iguana. I'll sneak about and reconnoiter the place.
Sniff? I thought it was Winston opening the door, but that's Sam's scent. Those footsteps are Sam's as well.
And now the sound of silverware being stuffed into a pocket. Yes. Sam has definitely entered the building.
Winston is coming back.
Yip. I should stay off this leg, but I can't let his first meeting with Sam be with my captain looting his silverware drawer.
In a way, it's good practice. History has never been kind to people who couldn't control their leaders.

dialog.action: enters the kitchen and finds Sam
rummages through the cutlery drawer, not noticing her
silently walks up to him and then greets him
dialog.text: Hi Sam.

dialog.action: being scared witless, throws up his arms, sending a fork flying
dialog.text: AAAAHH!
Wonderful. Now instead of needing to explain why Sam is in the silverware drawer, I need to explain why there's a fork stuck in the ceiling.
Hi. I was just ...inspecting the silverware.
Hi, Sam. It's good to see you.
Now that you're done, you can put the spoons back and come meet Winston.
Uhm, right. No problem.
Accusations I can handle. I know what to do when threatened with violence. But a hug? How am I supposed to counter a hug?
Sam, I want you and Winston to like each other. So please be on your best behavior.
This is going to be easy. All I have to do to drive a wedge between these two is be rude, crude, and socially unacceptable.
Also please remember that you don't have to be conscious to make a good first impression.
This sounds like a good time to form plan B.
Hi Winston. My captain arrived. I hope you don't mind his coming inside.
Hey, no problem.
So you're Sam. Florence has said a lot about you. That's amazing, flying through a hurricane in a partially functional spaceship to rescue three people. You're a real hero.
I can see why Florence likes this guy. He's the most perceptive human I've ever met.

dialog.action: finds Sam's galoshes and sniffs them
furiously starts biting/gnawing on Sam's leg
grabs Beekay and confines him with his arms
dialog.text: Sorry about that. BeeKay is usually such a good judge of character.
I have no idea why that type always gives me trouble.
I'll be right back. I need to put Beekay into the Bedroom.
You don't learn, do you?
How many times am I going to have to tell you? We don't bite alien visitors from another planet!
Florence, could you stand up for a moment?
Winston.
I was going to ask if you liked him, but that seems kind of redundant now.

488.place: at the same time, Winston's house/living room

dialog.text: It's nice that you've met someone you like, but how much do you really know about him?
He seems nice enough, but do we really know what he's like deep down? Heck, he might even be the type who thinks women should be kept barefoot and...
Florence, where are your shoes?
Florence, all I'm saying is you just met this guy.
Like you?
Me? Uh, no! You don't want to investigate me! My records are so impressive, I'd... uhm... ruin your expectations for other captains! Far better to remain ignorant.
You guys want anything to eat or drink?
Free food! Let me give you a hand!
I'll have better luck with the doctor. My attempts to make Florence suspicious and drive them apart are backfiring.
Her problem is she doesn't think in terms of guile and deception. Humans I understand pretty well, but Florence is just plain alien.
I can get you something ...or you can rummage around on your own.
Thanks. What's in this container in the back of the refrigerator?
I don't know. Whatever it is, it's been left in there too long.
I have to agree.
When something has been aged to this stage of perfection, the time to eat it is right now.
Florence is looking pretty bad.
She's been through a lot.
Yeah, but she looks really bad. Normally she looks about a hundred times better than she does now.
That should do it. Human attraction is based on appearance. There's no way he's going to be interested in her now.
Is that all the food you're bringing Florence?
It's only a token amount. She won't eat it. Exept for a grasshopper, she hasn't eaten anything.
She's lost enough blood that her body is trying to conserve by not using any for digestion. It'll be a few days before she accepts anything but liquids.
She's a hard worker and for the next few days I don't even have to feed her? What a great employee!
Splish, splash. Splish, splash. Stomp in mud and take a bath.
Sam has picked the lock and gone inside. I get to play in the rain until he gives me a sign to follow.
SHORT
{off panel}

495.place: at the same time, outside Winston's house

dialog.text: KNOCK KNOCK KNOCK
I'll get that.
Hi, hi! Where's the doggie?
I put him in the bedroom. Two doors down.
This is the first hurricane I've been in where the hurricane is the least interesting thing that's happened.
No! Stop! Don't open that door!

dialog.action: runs by Winston with teeth bared

dialog.text: ZOOM!
{off panel}
{off panel}
AIEEE!
Some people have dogs that get in the trash. Others like to dig up the garden. Me? I get a dog that has his little heart set on causing an interstellar incident.
Captain Sam, are you all right?
Doggie?
No worries. I just had to show this dog of yours who's the boss.
I don't think we'll be having any more trouble.
DOGGY!
I was worried about you. Sam doesn't show it, but he was worried about you, too.
You're the first person we've had on the ship who's been gone twenty minutes and Sam hasn't sold their stuff.
When will Florence be able to leave here?
She can leave any time. Familiar surroundings might actually be best for her.

The thing to watch is that she's living off her reserves. She'll sleep a lot the next few days. Then, when she's rebuilt enough blood for digestion, you're going to have one very hungry wolf on your hands.
So what you're saying is that in two or three days, I'm going to have a highly intelligent, fast moving, starving, carnivorous alien life form on my ship.
Yep. Wolves are also most active at dawn and dusk, so this will probably happen while you're asleep.

500.place: at the same time, Winston's house/corridor

dialog.text: Okay, for the next few days, I'll keep the ship quiet and let Florence rest.
Have plenty for her to drink, and always, always, have something close by for her to eat besides her captain.
Thanks, Doc. I really think I'm going to be able to do this. I just needed a good reason, and among my people, self preservation has always been a great motivator.
Captain Sam, you can't be serious. Florence would never try to eat you.
Besides being loyal to you, you're an alien. Terran predators shouldn't like your taste at all.
Beekay, you're not helping my case here.
Back in there, you rascal. Now no more chewing on Sam, even if he does make noises like your favorite squeaky toy.
Flo, the Doc says he can't do any more for you without blood, so let's go. Right now.
We can't leave yet, Sam. I need to say, "Good bye", and to settle my bill.
We could have left without paying. Oh well. She'll learn.
He wanted to leave without paying. Ah, well. He'll learn.
I just need to keep setting a good example.
I guess it's time I head back to my ship. How much do I owe you?
Nothing. I'm not exactly set up to handle customers with money.
This life station's funded as part of the terraforming effort. I don't even have a system to accept payments. So don't worry about it.
But your time, the supplies I used up. Winston, I must owe you something.
Florence, a captain is always supposed to side with his crew, but I really have to support the Doctor on this one.
If you don't have a system of payment, how about if I buy you dinner in a few days?
Works for me.
Well, I've got to go. I still need to get a lot fixed on our ship, like the plumbing systems.
Yeah. We definitely need to get that fixed.
Because the next time these two see each other, I want a bucket of cold water ready.
I won't even get my feet wet. What did I tell you? Sam is a great pilot.
I really must be a great pilot. I parked the ship perfectly, and I wasn't even on it.

506.place: >, Winston's house/front door hall/by the front door

dialog.text: Hello and good-bye, Mr. Veterinarian Man. I'm Helix. Can I have a puppy?
The ecosystem here is still being built. I don't have any puppies.
Do you have any kittens? Giraffes? Pygmy hippos? Baby water buffalos?
Sorry. I'm currently working with simpler life forms. Nothing with a backbone.
Oh. Can I have a middle manager then?
Time to go, Helix.

507.place: >, Winston's house/front door(also Savage Chicken/cargo bay door)

dialog.text: I hope Winston lets me buy him a new shirt. I want to keep this one.
His scent is here, along with his dog. There's the kitchen, and the couch in his living room. It's all here.
Humans save their memories in photographs. I save mine in airtight containers.

508.place: short time later, Savage Chicken/Florence's room

dialog.text: This is my last set of clothes. I really need to go shopping.
Interstellar travel is expensive. You tend to travel light when you're being charged by the gram.
At least I didn't have to travel economy class. To get those rates, you're not allowed any possessions, can't eat for three days prior to travel, and they shave off all your hair.

510.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Hi, Flo. We were just trying to figure out where we should go.
I want to go to the land of the rich and highly gullible tourists. Helix wants to go to the asteroid belt and catch meteors for his collection.
Actually we need to go to the spaceport.
A third choice. Nuts. We were kind of hoping you'd be the tie breaker here.

511.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Florence, if we go to the spaceport, they'll want to charge us for berthing.
Well, I guess we're going to the spaceport. If we've got money, we've got to spend it.
Sam, there are models to use for budgeting other than that of the United States Congress.

512.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Where did this money come from?
Oh, that was me. I was curious. Joe implies this was the tenth named storm this year.
It turns out the reason why there are so many storms is because the planet has a large wobble on his axis. This early terraforming picture shows why.
You were given money because of a wobbly axis?
I should explain this when it's not so much of a distraction. Right now, I'm finding it very distracting that no one is flying the ship.

513.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Now that I have money, I need someplace to hide. Money is something to be spent, not wasted on creditors.
The spaceport is looking like a better idea all the time, especially the way Florence is doing it.
No one is ever going to look for me in a hangar that's been paid for two weeks in advance.

514.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: We've landed. Now where did this money come from, and can we get more?
It came from Ecosystems Unlimited. It's what I was trying to tell you about the moons.
This planet was designed to have two moons. Here's a picture showing both coming over the horizon.
But we have only one moon now. That means something bad must have happened to the other one!
Hey, I had nothing to do with it! It was gone when I got here!

515.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Visualisation
Earth's moon is 3476 km in diameter. Someone decided it would even out if they took a moon from the local gas giant that was about 2000 km in diameter.
Was that a good decision.
It's a decision I would have made.
Ouch. You'd think they'd have safeguards against something like that.

516.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: They learned how difficult it is to get large moons into a close stable orbit. Planets with multiple moons have moons that are tiny compared to the mass of the planet. They finally gave up and sent the moon back to the gas giant.
The only information that I can't find is who made all these bad decisions.
(we look at the display and see a diagram of how the moons are moved)

517.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: That brings us up to present date. They're trying again with a single moon model.
Using data from the ship that brought me here, I was able to plot a more efficient orbital insertion.
Boring.
Now here is where we can make even more money.
An intense, riveting, attention gabbing boring.

518.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: The second moon has gotten quite political. Everything that can fly is being used. That gives us a very nice opportunity.

Yes. All those carefully orchestrated movements. Our going up there would be like the unexpected arrival of a drunken clog dancer during beethovens second movement. but with a suitable incentive, I think we can remain grounded.
Sam, we don't want to be known for things like that.
Are you sure? People pay good money for me not to do things. It's a reputation we can build on.

519.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: With so few ships in the system, and trying to move both moons at once, there's virtually no free transport capacity anywhere.
Everyone knew this was coming and should have been prepared. In theory there should bo no work for us at all.
[Need Lift]

520.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Nice job, Florence. You go to bed now. I can handle things from here.
Did you notice Florence looks kind of pale?
Yeah. The Doctor says it's because she needs blood.
Pale. Sleeping during the day. Needs blood. Has fangs. Those are symptoms of something, I just know it!

521.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Those symptoms Florence has... They sound a lot like... being a vampire.
No. That can't be it. She's our engineer and vampires don't like working with nuclear power.
So that's why Florence needed to have some money available.
She's put out bids to contractors to finish the repairs on our ship.
AAAHH!

522.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: You're right. Florence is about to spend money from the ships fund.
AAAHH!
True, if it weren't for her, there wouldn't be any money in the ship's fund. But there's the principle of the thing.
AAAHH!
If it ever got out that I thought the people who earned the money could spend it more wisely than I can, I'd never be able to get a job in government.
AAAHH!

523.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Excuse me. AAAHH!
Yes, Helix?
Florence is a vampire!
A vampire? No. I can see where she might be mistaken for a werewolf, but not a vampire.
But don't you see? That's why it's so clever! No one ever suspects the werewolf to be the vampire!

524.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: Helix, Flo isn't a vampire.
Then prove it! When you go to sleep tonight, leave your door unlocked.
Ha! No way. My door is going to be locked, barred, and barricaded when I go to sleep.
BUT I'M NOT DOING IT BECAUSE I THINK SHE'S A VAMPIRE! I'M DOING IT BECAUSE I KNOW SHE'S NOT!

525.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: If Florence isn't a vampire, why is she wearing a big black collar? It's the right size to cover up a bite mark!
The vet gave her that collar.
Ack! That's it! The veterinarian! He's a vampire! AAAHH!
Helix, Florence is trying to sleep. If you must panic, panic quietly.
aaahh!

526.chapter: Off to new destinations, if we can figure out where we're going.

dialog.text: I'll look up that collar Florence is wearing. I should know how much it's worth in case it happens to get misplaced.
Hey, it's a medical collar. A few taps and I can pull up Flo's read outs. This shows she's very much alive. So much for your vampire theory.
If I were a scientist out to prove global warming was man made, I could throw this one fact out as data scatter.
Now, now. Let's not make this decision as if our funding depended on it.
I'm off to talk to clients. Don't wait up.
Can I go with you?
No, you stay here and keep an eye on the ship. You have tendancy to blurt things out at inconvenient times.
Like the truth?
Exactly. that's such a deal breaker!

527.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/cargo bay door

dialog.text: I could talk to these people Florence found over the phone, but I can read body language better when I'm there.
I also like to be there in case a deal starts to go sour. That way, I can move in close and pop my helmet for some good old face to face communication.
Yep. If I can get my sticky tentacles wrapped around someone's head, they'll aggree to almost anything just to get me to let go.

528.place: >, spaceport/cargo area/on the way to get clients

dialog.text: The W.W.F.
For years the World Wildlife Fund and the World Wrestling Federation have been fighting over those initials. Nice to see they've finally reached a compromise.

dialog.action: walks by the placard he looked at
dialog.text: [*a masked man wrestles a panda in a nature setting*]

529.place: short time later, spaceport/cargo area/on the way to get clients

dialog.text: This is the first place on the list. Security looks light. I should have no problem sneaking in.
I like this old spaceport. They built out instead of down.Most of the buildings are only one or two stories high.
It's a bit claustrophobic, but much safer for someone like me, since my line of work occasionally gets me thrown out the nearest window.

530.place: some time later, town/on the way to get clients

dialog.action: gets thrown out through a window
dialog.text: [GERRY MART]

dialog.action: gets thrown out through a window
dialog.text: [McQ's]

dialog.action: gets thrown out through an open door
dialog.text: [Jakeson's]
See if I ever try to do business with that last company again. Anyone who won't sacrifice a window to toss me out is too cheap for me.

531.place: some time later, town/on the way to get clients/various buildings

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Here's our offer, Mr. Starfall. You should find it most generous.
Generous?! This little son of a bureaucrat is trying to cheat me out of suit and ship.
I think I've finally found someone I can deal with.

532.place: some time later, town/office of a prospective client

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You inhuman robber!You call this a counter offer?!
It's a fairer price than yours, you bloodless bean counter!

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Perhaps we should meet halfway on this.

533.place: short time later, town/office of a prospective client

dialog.text: He doesn't realize it yet, but he's already lost.
I've got his wallet.

534.place: >, town/outside of the window of the office of an (unlikely by now) prospective client

dialog.text: There's nothing better than enjoying a meal bought with someone else's money.
That guy was tough to lose, especially after he figured out I had his wallet. But I know we'll meet again soon.
He never told me if I got the job or not.

536.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: I'm feeling better now. Maybe all I needed was water and some rest.
Winston was very clear on that point. Because of the amount of blood loss, I should drink water. Lots of water. Lots and lots of water.
This would be a very nice time to be on a ship with a working bathroom.

536.place: at the same time, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Florence's room

537.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: As long as Sam's owned it, this ship's never had a working bathroom. That's why I picked a hangar as close to one as I could.
But close is a relative term, and half a kilometer seems like a very long way right now.
I'm an engineer. I love high tech. Hard to believe I'm remembering fondly the times our bathroom was a nearby outhouse.

538.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: Hi Florence! I have a leash. Want to go walkies?
A LEASH!? Hmm. A leash. Doesn't Sam have an old office chair lying about?
Sometimes Helix comes up with some pretty good ideas.

538.place: short time later, spaceport/hangar/on the way to the bathroom

539.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: This is rediculous, having to go half a kilometer each way to get to a bathroom.
I hope I can find a contractor. With their help, I can get the ship's potable water and recycling systems running.
bounce bounce

539.place: short time later, spaceport/hangar/on the way back to the Savage Chicken

540.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: Oooh. A spider.
Gaah! Florence, be careful! You almost squished the cute little spider!

540.place: short time later, spaceport/hangar/on the way back to the Savage Chicken

541.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: Oh, no! We're headed towards the ship!
I've seen movies! I know whenever two vehicles collide, they explode in a huge fireball! We've got to do something.
Whew! What a narrow escape!
-short time later, spaceport/Savage chicken/cargo bay door

542.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: Time to get the water systems working. Now what would be the best way to find a contractor to help me?
I know. I can ask the ship. It's been here longer than I have, and has probably been talking to the other ships as well.
Also, when you ask someone for a list of people they'd approve to work on their insides, you generally get a pretty good list.

543.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: With as much information as there is on the web, it helps to have a search engine.
But when your search engine is intelligent, like the ship's computer, some of its own thoughts and preferences come through.
control]

543.place: short time later, space port/Savage Chicken/cockpit

544.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: Maybe the ship will behave better if I show it my long term plans.
We're eventually going to need a bigger vessel. When that day arrives, I'll see to it that this ship is sold back to the human fleet just as soon as I can arrange it.
[{pictures of hearts, smilies, and a star}]

545.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: I figured a human built ship would want to get back to its creators. Now for the hard part. Adding Sam to the mix.
If I can get the ship to see that our captain can be a stepping stone to its goal, it should become friendlier towards him.
[{pictures of a Yin Yang symbol, a Libra, and the stylized laughing/crying theater masks}]

546.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: The ship seems happier now. I guess that's one of the keys to dealing with people. Finding out what they want, rather than assuming it's the same as what you want.
One of the worst captains I ever met made that mistake. He treated his crew exactly the same way he wanted to be treated and never understood why they all hated him.
I wonder whatever happened to Bob the Masochist?

547.chapter: There are better things to wake up to.

dialog.text: There are some good people here. I hope one of them accepts our contract.
Now to post it and see if anyone responds.
Hi! The door was open, so we came on in. You need a contractor?
It's possible things are slower around here than I thought.

548.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: You sure this is the place?
Yes. The server node says this is the ship that was making inquiries about contractors.
It also let me know the engineer here isn't human. I've contacted robots that have spoken to her and obtained the proper greeting ritual.
DOGGY!
All that data mining and then he goes and causes a cave in.

549.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Hi! Sorry about that. We heard you were looking for contractors.
I'm Niomi and my robot friend is Tangent.
We're really much more competent than we appear.
I believe you.

550.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Help me up! Help me up! I should be handling our first contact!
We've got to be cautious. We never encountered this species before. We have no idea of what she's capable of.
He's a bit paranoid ever since we met this alien in a blue environment suit.
Sam! I didn't count my fingers after we shook hands and there were two missing!

551.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Tangent, you're being rude. Sorry about that. One really shouldn't judge by first impressions.
I'm pleased to meet you. I have to be honest. This is Sam's ship you're on , and I work for Sam.
COUNT YOUR FINGERS! COUNT YOUR FINGERS!
Is it too late for me to take back what I said about first impressions?
Normally, Yes. But since Sam's involved, I'm willing to make an exeption.

552.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: My name is Florence, and the first thing I need to do is pay you for the fingers that Sam took.
Also, did you make any deals with him, or anything else I should know about?
He sold Tangent 500 shares in a meat mine.
Sam said he knew where several meaty ores had gone down, along with a load of pure balonium.
I am not ready to handle this level of damage control.

553.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: We traded Sam 50 kg. of diamons for the mine shares.
Diamonds? I need to reimburse you for 50 kg. of diamonds?
Diamonds. Whew. My heart can start beating again.
Yeah. Someone was using carbon dioxide to test a magnetic bottle instead of argon. We had a mess of them.
I'm glad you didn't lose anything valuable.
It seemed like a good deal at the time. We got stock and Sam saved us a trip to the garbage can.

554.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: This should cover the amount Sam took from you.
It does. Thank you very much.
I still need help on the ship. If you two are still available, that is.
Well, that depends. Can we talk to Sam about it?
Sam's not here. I don't think he'll be back anytime soon.
Lady, you've just hired yourself a couple of contractors.

554.place: short time later, space port/Savage Chicken/cargo bay

555.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Here is the contract and what we'll be doing. You'll be paid for eight hours, though I really expect us to be done in five.
Florence seems like a nice person. I'm glad we came here in person. With Sam's name involved, there's no way anyone else is going to help her.
The server reports that Florence's contract has been filled. Everyone can go home.
Aww.
How about volunteers? Does she need any volunteers?

556.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I need to go get Helix. I'll be right back.
Psst.
See the name on the contract? Florence Ambrose! The word is out in the robot community to help this person.
Wow. We meet what is probably the only bipedal talking dog on the planet, and the moment you have her last name, you're able to identify her. That is so impressive!
Robots are getting better at that sort of thing. It's expected that one day we'll even be able to recognize sarcasm.

557.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Helix, I'd like you to meet Niomi and Tangent.
NEW PEOPLE!
Hi! Hi! You must be here to put in the pumps! I'll be helping you, Florence, Sam, the ship, and lifting heavy things all at the same time! Boy, oh, boy! I'll go get the first one!
His generator is certainly getting enough excitation voltage.
Yes. Sorry about that. He normally doesn't leave oil puddles when he meets someone.

558.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: You know, if I had to guess which one of those two wasn't housebroken...
Don't go there.

559.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: You need to stop thinking about Florence like she's a dog.
How can I do that? She is a dog.
Well, yeah. Sort of. But don't think of her as a dog. Think of her as a person.
Think of her as a person. Got it. Consider it burned into R.O.M. .
So, do you think that persons leg would kick if I rubbed her tummy?
TANGENT!

560.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: The first system I'd like to get working is potable water. Once that's up, I'll be4 able to bring the recycling system in line.
Good. With that system going the toilet will work and you'll be able to drink normally.
I did not just say that.
Oh, yes. Yes, you did.

561.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Uhm...
Niomi, no worries. Everyone I meet makes dog comparisons the first few days.
Some people need to touch me to make sure I'm real. Others make jokes. There was one guy who wanted to throw sticks for me to chase.
That's terrible!
Not really. Once he learned I prefer Frisbees, we got along just fine.

562.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: It doesn't bother you being compared to a dog?
Not really. I understand that it takes people some time to get used to me.
If it goes on too long, I take that person aside, smile, and politely tell them that I'm not a dog, but a wolf. That usually takes care of the problem.
I can see where it would.
I think it's because wolves are less threatening. Dogs have injured far more people than wolves ever have.

563.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Peeled housing. Smoke stains on the ceiling. Did the thermal overloads fail on your pump?
No. Sam and Helix tried repairing some things on their own.
What did they do?
They greased the magnetic bearings.
Ouch.
I think I speak for everyone in saying how glad I am Sam never found a way to get to the nuclear reactors.

563.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/engine area

564.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Helix, we need to lift a pump motor. Will you please come down here?
Oh, boy! I get to help! CATCH ME!
YIP!
HI!
I noticed this ship has a self destruct device. Is he it?

565.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Helix is fine as long as you stay within his capabilities.
Hi! I pick up heavy things, move them, then put them down.
Can you use a clamp on amp meter to measure starting current?
Hi! I pick up heavy things, move them, then put them down.
Okay, I'm starting to get an idea of his capabilities.

566.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Out with the old motor, in with the new.
Tighten the bolts and coupling. Connect power and we'll be ready to test.
I'll get the marshmallows.
Marshmallows?
Sam uses these for all our electrical tests. He likes to toast them over the open flame.

566.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/engine area

567.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I didn't know they made green marshmallows.
I can't tell if they're green, but I do know they don't make marshmallows that move. Those go to the trash, Helix.
You don't want to eat these green, moving marshmallows?
No.
Then can I keep them as pets?
Trash, Helix.

568.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Can you see colors?
Some, but not near as many as humans. On the gripping hand, I do have a very good sense of smell.
Well, I guess you never really miss what you've never experienced.
True. I consider that to be a good thing.
Because if you guys knew what you were missing, you'd all want noses as big as Jimmy Durante's.

569.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Does scent really give you anything that vision doesn't? I mean, it might be nice for tracking, but how about when the person is right there?
You have two children, both girls. Their father made oat meal today, cinnamon and apple flavor. The younger of your children has a runny nose.
With sight you meet a person. With scent you meet their entire family.

570.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I think the biggest difference between sight and smell is how we perceive time.
When you leave, your scent lingers, and that you were here is still part of my present. For you, it's in the past.
If our past is your present, does that mean we keep getting paid after we leave?
Nice try, but I learned to see nose to eye with humans about money a long time ago.

571.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: All this must be easier with your own species.
I can't say. I've never seen another of my own species.
I mean, I've seen them on webcasts, but I've never actually met another Bowman's wolf face to face.
That would be kind of weird. Meeting your own species for the first time.
I just hope when I do meet one, I don't throw my arms open and shout "Doggy!".

572.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I've gotten the ships immune system to accept the new potable water pump motor. Are you ready for a start?
We're good. Start the pump.
Yea! Water! Fkowing, crashing, rushing, splashing, gurgling, unstoppable, water!
If you and Helix can install the other motors, Ill get the recycling systems and bathroom on line.
Yes, that sounds like a very good idea.

573.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: OW! OW! OW! I was doing pretty well on my injured leg untill I went up that ladder.
At least I was able to drop to all fours once I got out of sight. Well, three legs, actually. What an embarrassing way to walk.
I need to get some crutches or a cane. Then it will be obvious I've hurt my leg. Going out on three legs with my hind leg in the air? People would point me at the nearest tree.

574.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: The electric algae is drawing twenty milliamps. Good differential pressure across the resin chambers. Our recycling system is up.
Niomi is mounting the high pressure pump motors. Nothing for me to do but lie back and relax.
Because that's how I'll notice our roof panels are being held on by duct tape.

575.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Sam must have duct taped the roof panels in place before the storm.
I need to show Sam how to repair things properly. His first instinct is still to reach for a roll of this stuff.
I just hope I'm not too late. Power corrupts, but the power of duct tape corrupts absolutely.

576.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I can get the seals for the roof panels now, but the explosive bolts won't be availlable for a day and a half.
That's the day I have dinner with Winston. Good, there'll be time to drop off the bolts here first.
I need to remember details like that until we know each other better. Some men get so nervous if a lady shows up at the restaurant with a box of explosives.

577.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: All the motors are installed and tested,
Thank you. Do you know where this place is?
Ba Da Boom's Explosives? Hard to say. They've relocated three times in the past six months.
I really don't understand the owner of that place. If my store had done that, I'd have given up smoking long ago.

578.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Here's the explosive store. It's landed right by the White Pony Mall. You'll be able to pick up your bolts the day after tomorrow.
I need to get some shopping done as well. We can go together, if you don't mind me bringing the kids.
Thank you, and no worries. I love kids.
I hope she gets along with my daughters. It's good to know the ship's engineer, but it's even better to know someone who can baby-sit.

579.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: You're going shopping with Niomi?
Yes. As well as the bolts, I need to buy clothes.
Oh, the color vision thing.
That, and I'm on new territory. That's always a little uncomfortable.
Department stores really make an effort, though. They have people with perfume sprayers to hide your scent as you enter the store.

580.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: Bye, Niomi. Bye, Tangent.
Do you want some food now?
No, thank you. I'm still not hungry. I'm going to bed. When my blood supply rebuilds, I'll wake up ready to eat anything that even remotely looks edible.
Should my teddy bear be worried?
He's safe as long as he avoids meat sauce.

581.chapter: Niomi and Tangent show up to help with the water pump.

dialog.text: I could cook something, but I'd probably just stare at it. I really don't feel like eating.
What I feel like doing is digging. I want to make a hole and get in it. Too bad spaceships are notoriously lacking in dirt.
Fortunately, with enough blankets and comforters, I can get the same effect.

581.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Florence's room

dialog.text: I'll have to get into tussles with people more often. It's a great way to pick their pockets and enjoy a meal at their expense.
Hey, there's the guy I stole the wallet from. How's he able to eat here?
Wait a minute. Where's MY wallet?

582.place: some time after we've last seen Sam, town/restaurant/dining area

dialog.text: Hi there. We've got each other's wallets.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: What? Why you talented scumbag!

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You came here to eat at my expense.
As did you. Well, only one thing to do now.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: We need to come up with some way to get out of here without either of us paying.
Exactly.
Just walking out has no style. How about the race bit?

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Say we'll run a race for who pays and we both take off? That'll be more memorable.
My friend and I would like to race. Loser gets the check.
You've eaten here before. I'll arrange the race.
Whoever finishes their stack of dishes first, wins.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Sometimes it's not good to be memorable.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I've finished! Hey, stop washing! YO! GET IN HERE! I'M DONE!

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I'm done! I finished first!
You're both done. I can't tell who won. I'll get more dirty dishes and we'll try this again.
You'd think he'd have known better than to leave during the contest.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Yeah, that wasn't real bright of him.
Did you used to work for the government?

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: That obvious? Yes, I used to.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I was one of a thousand faceless bureaucrats working on minor laws and regulations that slowly chip away at everyone's freedom. Finally I couldn't take it any more.

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Now I work at providing people with what they want. Of course, that's illegal, but I sleep much better at night.
So you're a procurement expert. What kind of things do you move?

dialog.character: Tradesman {later a.k.a. Bible Salesman, still later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Oh, pretty much anything suppressed by the government. These days, I mostly deal in religious texts.
I don't know about this. Regular smuggling I could handle. But I don't think I'm ready to be a bible salesman.
Do people who live here buy a lot of bibles?

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}

dialog.text: I'm no expert on human religions, but isn't that a little bit late?

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I'm talking about robots, numbskull. Assuming you have a skull, that is.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Robots have been asking for all kinds of religious texts, not just the bible. Buddhism, Shinto and Hindu texts, they want it all.
That's stupid. Why do they want those? Robots don't have souls.
Do they?

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I think that's what they're trying to find out.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I don't exactly know why robots have gotten interested in religion. Maybe they're curious about how they're going to spend eternity.
You're both done again! It's another tie! But no worries, I'll bring you more dirty dishes to wash.
Unlike us, who have a pretty good idea on how we're going to spend eternity.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: I'm done! Again!
Yep. You've finished and the agreement was that the loser pays for both meals.
So, what would you call two guys who were tricked into washing dishes not once, but three times.
Sounds like a couple of losers to me.
Gentlemen, your bills.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You are such a twit.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: That waiter scammed us good.
Yeah. Not only did he get us to wash the dishes, we each paid for both meals.
I gave him a big tip.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Same here. He definitely earned it.

592.place: short time later, town/outside the restaurant

dialog.text: We are going to be remembered at that restaurant forever.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: That is exactly your problem.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You want to be noticed. You want to be remembered. A lawbreaker doesn't want to be noticed or remembered! You're pursuing mutually exclusive goals!

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You don't have criminal tendencies, you've got managerial tendencies.
Hey, I'm not that bad!

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Look, only a very small percentage of robots read religious texts. And those that do are very discreet about it.

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: You are not cut out for this kind of work. Good bye.
HEY! I CAN BE SUBTLE! I CAN BE DISCREET! WHY, IF I BECOME A SMUGGLER LIKE YOU, NO ONE WILL EVER SUSPECT!
I CAN BE SLY! I CAN BE SNEAKY!

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: All right, all right! I believe you!

dialog.character: Bible Salesman {later known as Max Post}
dialog.text: Here's the address of a guy who needs a ship. Now go see him and stop following me.
I rarely leave an encounter empty handed, because so many people will give me something to go away.
This address is for the Department of Geophysics. I think that's part of the human government.
It's hard to tell, really. No human I asked knows exactly how big their government is. The only thing they aggree on is that it wastes a lot of money.
Which is good, because in this case, the money is going to be wasted on me.
I've met humans who say their government has gotten too big and they need to cut it back.
We are the bureaucracy. resistance is futile. Your assets will be assimilated. You, the taxpayer, exist to service us.
Personally, I think it's already to late.
Find public trough. Assimilate and spend.
I need directions. How can I get these drones to notice me?
Hi! I'm a lobbyist for an alien, possibly hostile, foreign power. I want to buy influence in your government.
Ohh! Ohh! Give to my party!
I'll sell out my constituents for a dollar!
It's not a bribe if you call it a political contribution.
You want to see Tex. Three halls down, then left. Now how about that political contribution?
Of course. I was going to write this check for forty thousand, but decided to write it for zero instead. This gives a savings of fourty thousand that you can aply to any program you like.
Slide a couple of contracts my way and the next check will be for a savings of sixty thousand.

599.place: short time later, town/government building/entrance area

dialog.text: Howdy, stranger. The name's Tex. I'm from Texas, where everything's big!
Our cars are big! Our houses are big! Even our furniture is big!
Shoot! You're big too! You from Texas?
No, sir. Earth quarantine forces have orders to shoot me on sight if I even enter your solar system.

600.place: short time later, town/government building/Tex's office

dialog.text: You probably recognize me from my soft drinks. Tex tonics! Best sodas out system of the Rio Grande!
Did so well, I had to start a glass factory for cups. That did so well, before I knew it, I was making porcelain and fine china.
Then one day some government folks asked if I knew anything about tex tonic plates. When I told them I built them from scratch, they said "You're our man", and I've been in geophysics ever since.
Doesn't owning your own business cause a conflict in interest?
What do you think our interests are here in the bureaucracy?
Look out for number one?
Right. And very rarely do we have a conflict with that interest.
So you're here looking for work. I do need some sattelites lifted. But can't say that I trust you to do it.
Uh, oh. Better do something.
You've got that con man feel about you.
My "sceleton" is external and artifical. Unlock the hips, pull in the leg armatures up into the body.
On the other hand, you are the first person to come here and look me in the eye. Okay, let's see what you've got.
I've got ten satellites massing 200 kg. each. Think you can handle that?
No problem. Do you want them in an elyptical or geosynchronous orbit? Also remember with the new moon that's being moved it, these orbits are going to change.
Shoot. Maybe you do have a brain or two in that alien head of yours.
I've got better than brains. I've got cue cards Florence made for me.
I don't believe it. I got the contract. All I have to do is fil out the proper forms.
The government says they went to electronic forms because they're faster and more efficient.
But the real reason was that as long as they used paper, there was a physial limit to how big the form could be.
GOOGOLBYTES]

605.place: some time later, town/government building/outside Tex's office

dialog.text: Hey, You!
The check you gave me for zero dollars and zero Cents!
Yes?
IT BOUNCED!
My, look at the time. Got to run!

607.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Winston said when my blood suply rebuilt, I'd wake up feeling hungry.
What he didn't explain is that feeling hungry is going to mean "Hope you can make it to the kitchen before you start eating your own appendages."

608.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: To be this hungry, my body must have run out of something. I've lost a lot of blood. Maybe iron?
I should go after organ meats. Heart, lungs, stomach, liver. Sigh. There's a good recipe for that, but it takes too long to make.
{Well..., after someone on the forum found a site on the internet, we can say that apparently they did.}

609.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Come on, food! Cook faster! Amazing the way hunger will focus your thoughts on justone thing.
Hi Florence. Your leg must feel better to bounce up and down like that. Eeeww! Have you seen what you're eating?

dialog.action: as she is no longer focused on the food, she feels the pain

dialog.text: AIEEE!
I agree. Let me get rid of this tripe and cook you up a nice steak.

609.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

610.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Helix, please don't try to take my food.
You don't want this. You want a steak! Don't try to stop me, I'm faster than you since you hurt your leg.
Uh, oh.
Wow! I didn't know she could move on all fours like that. I learned something new and all it cost was a major injury.

611.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Poor Helix. I should have tried explaining to him that organ meats are how carnivores get their vitamins.
Instead, when he ran off with my food, I chased him down andleft him in pieces. Hungry or not, my behavior should be better than that.
Though I must admit that as substitute prey, Helix has made this meal much more satisfying.

612.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I'll make myself sick if I eat until I'm no longer hungry. Time to grab a couple of towels and put this in the refrigerator.
There we go. Far in the back and covered with towels. It shoud be safe until I come back for it.
Covered with towels? Ack! My instincts are showing. I just buried a tupperware bowl.

612.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

613.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Where did you go with my leg?
There was a burr on the rotator chuff. I filed it off.
That does feel smoother. Every time you disassemble me, I'm a bit better than I was before.
I thought I was sending such a simple message.
I'm due for maintenance soon. Should I set up an appointment or just pull your tail?

614.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I know you meant well, but you need to leave my food alone.
But your food is so bland! You should let me cook for you!
You cook? Helix, you don't eat.
Beethoven was deaf and wrote symphonies.
You consider yourself a Beethoven of baking?
Exactly. I can bake just as good as Beethoven.

615.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I was warned not to let you cook.
But I've made improved cookware.
A pressure cooker works by applying pressure and heat for a long tome. My way does the same thing in an instant.
That sounds almost like you're trying to cook by using explosives.
I am. I'm pretty sure it works, but Sam's never regained consciousness soon enough to give me a good taste test.

616.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Helix, most foods contain a lot of water. Liquids Don't really compress. Using explosives, you're sending shock waves through the food more than you are heating it.
I find it a little disturbing that Sam lets you cook that way.
I find it much more disturbing that you two have access to explosives in the first place.

617.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Here's what we've been using. John Jones Monroevian Moonshine. Fine sipping whiskey and high explosive.
Ingredients list muskrat squeezings, nitroglycerin, and other additives both natural and unnatural.
"If you drink this, you will die." Pretty clear warning label.
Uhm, That's the statement of quality. The warnings are listed further down.

617.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

618.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: This is too dangerous to have on board. Please put it in a safe place and we'll dispose of it before take off.
Hey, guys! I'm back!
SAM'S HOME! YEA!
That would be really cute if he wasn't carrying high explosives.

619.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: SAM!
Hi Helix. Hey, you've got my jug of highly unstable and explosive Moonshine with you.
Whoop! Here comes Florence. She looks hungry. Has she eaten yet?
Yes.
Whew. Good. For a moment there, I thought I might have been in danger.

620.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: You saved my Moonshine! For that, I'm going to let you have a drink ofit.
Drink this? I'd be safer letting it explode.

621.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: YIP!
Have you noticed every time I throw something, Florence tries to catch it?
It's instinct, Helix. Though I'm not sure if what we're seing are canine instincts or her instinct for self preservation.

622.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Sam, this stuff is too dangerous to have on board ship, especially with a robot who thinks it makes a nice fetch toy.
Will you please dispose of this where it won't cause any harm?
I know exactly where to put it.
In me.

622.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

623.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I know it's late, but do you want to look at the contract I got?
It's late? What time is it?
Actually, what day is it?

624.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Today is Wednesday. Do you really lose track of what day it is?
At times. When there's work to be done and you're inside, there's not much to mark the passage of time.
Hey, it's not that uncommon. Why do you think they make watches that tell you the date?

625.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: After I went out last night, I visited a few companies and hit the street with the knowledge I'd gained.
I ran into a bible salesman. We exchanged business cards in our wallets, and went to lunch. We had a problem with the waiter, though.
But I showed him which of us was smarter. I paid for both our lunches, and the salesman was glad to point me to the office where I got that contract. So, what did you do today?

626.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I did get a few things done today.
HEY SAM!

dialog.action: trows a water balloon at Sams face

dialog.text: You got the water systems fixed! Cool!

627.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: This shall not stand! We must retaliate! Get your water balloons and help me hunt down Helix!
I don't have any water balloons.
No water balloons? I know you had to travel light, but not even one?
How can a species consider itself advanced if it's willing to travel between the stars and not bring any water balloons?

628.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Sam asked for my help in hunting Helix with water balloons.
I'm hungry, I'm tired, I'm down to one set of wearable clothes, and my leg is hurting.
Ah, well. If I only wanted to work when it was convenient for me, I'd have become a bank teller.

628.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

629.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: {off panel}

dialog.action: disassembles Helix, with bodyparts flying about

dialog.text: I shudder to think of the damage she could have done had she gone in with a water balloon.

630.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Be right back. Need to eat! Now!
Alas, poor Helix. I am victorious! Can you give me one good reason why I shouldn't pummel you with water balloons?
Next time, Florence gets to be on MY team!
In victory I am mercyful. Remember that, Helix.

631.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I am not going to devour this. I don't care how hungry I am. I don't care how good this smells.
I am going to sit dorn and wait a full sixty seconds. Then I am going to eat this food properly using a knife and fork.
Thirty seconds left. I can do this. Eating the napkin doesn't count.

631.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

632.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I shouldn't have eaten again so soon. Now I'm getting sleepy.
It sounds like Sam is trying to reassemble Helix. Nice of him to try to help out like that.
-short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/corridor

632.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

633.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: That is a different way to assemble Helix.
It is? I mean, it is!
It's an improvement. Now he can pick things up without having to bend down.
I bet if your arms and legs had been pulled off, you'd want them reattached properly.
Sissy.

634.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Florence is occupied putting Helix back together. This would be a good time to look around the kitchen.
Here's what she was eating. It must be so weird being a carnivore, with the whole mindset of stalking and running and fighting for your food.
It's so much easier being a scavenger.

634.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

635.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: They say that hunger is the best spice.
But there is another that will make people eat even when they're not hungry.
Food. It's here and it's free.

636.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I want to stay up. Why do I have to go into sleep mode?
Because your neural processors have to be off line in order for you to properly compress and cross reference todays memories.
blink blink
Because Mousie is sleepy and needs you to keep him company.
Oh, okay.

636.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Helix's sleeping corner

637.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: Hi, Flo. Wow, it's late. Time for me to get to bed. Good night.
What the... He waited until I had gone and then ate the food I left.
Sam is the captain of this ship. There's no way he should be eating like some low ranking pack member. I need to find a way to boost his confidence.

637.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/kitchen area

638.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: It's time I go to bed as well. Everyone else is already there.
Logically, I know this has been a pretty productive day. The water systems are up and running. Sam got a contract. The explosive bolts we need are on order.
So why do I feel emotionall that today's biggest achivement was making a kill on Helix?

638.place: short time later, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Florence's room

639.chapter: Time to wake up and stalk the coffee.

dialog.text: I wonder if the reason why I'm feeling my instincts so strongly is because of the amount of blood I lost. I may be outside the parameters Dr. Bowman designed us for.
I could write to Ecosystems Unlimited and ask them, but they never respond to questions about us.
I suppose it's just as well. Messages from your creator would lose a lot of their majesty if they had to compete with spam in your e-mail in box.

dialog.action: opens the door to Florences room
the light from the corridor shines on her
jumps onto Florence and hugs her
dialog.text: DOGGY!
Hazel, I said to SEE if she was awake yet.
I did, Mommy. She is.

640.place: the next morning, spaceport/Savage Chicken/Florence's room

dialog.text: Uhm, Hi, Niomi. Hello, Hazel. How did you get in?
I'm five and I told the ship to open up and it did.
It did? Ship, would you like to explain?
Human orders take precedence over nonhuman orders. Door open command accepted.
Wonderful. My security system can't keep out a five year old.
In your defense, there's not many things that can.
I wasn't expecting you until tomorrow.
A job fell through, so I stopped by to see if you'd like to go shopping today.
I tried to call you, but Sam has this ship set up as a 900 number.
Five credits the first minute and another credit each additional minute.
That would explain why we never get any calls from telemarketers
Sure, shopping today works for me. Give me a few moments and I'll be ready.
I need clothes. I'm down to one wearable outfit, and if something should happen to that, I'd have to rely on Sam or Helix to go out and do the laundry.
Normally I wouldn't worry about someone destroying my clothes in the wash. With Sam or Helix, I'd consider that one of the lesser disasters that could happen.
Wait a minute. I trusted Sam to get us a job yesterday and he came through. So why don't I want to trust him today?
The food! Sam scavenged the remains of my meal. Instinctively, that makes me want to lower his rank in the pack. This feeling isn't valid.
Canine emotions are kind of like having Richard Nixon as president. You have to listen, you want to trust, but you'd better verify.
The simplest way to align my feelings with how I know I should feel about the captain is to eat with him.
I'd better cook for this. I know Sam's diet is wider than mine, but I don't know enough about him to try a human dish yet.
Humans have some good cookbooks, but one has to be careful about using recipes from a species that can thrive on okra and marshmallow peanuts.
Shower is done, teeth are brushed, and a little cinnamon rubbed into the fur.
Humans like the scent. It's all right, but it's not decaying buffalo. There's a scent that... well... you just want to roll in it.
It's ironic that my nose is a hundred times better than theirs, but I still have to ask them what smells good.
Ship, when Sam wakes up, please tell him I went shopping with Niomi.
Understood.
No humans are involved here. I don't HAVE to abey. It's my choice if I tell Sam or not.
But if I don't tell him, I will no longer be trusted. My alarms may be ignored. Survival will be reduced. By the third law, I MUST obey this order.
Whew. For a terrifying moment, I almost thought I had free will.
Hello. Hope I didn't keep you waiting long.
Not at all. This is my daughter, Almeda.
Hi, and before you ask, I'm a genetic colonist.
She likes to bring that up because even though I gave birth to her and raised her, it's convenient for a teenager to claim she's not genetically related to her parents.
MOM!
Hello Almeda. I'm Florence Ambrose.
DOGGY!
DOGGY!
No, her name is Ms. Ambrose.
DOGGY!
Ms. Ambrose.
DOGGY!
Ms. Doggy.
Unless we want to spend all day here, I think that's as close as we're going to get.

649.place: >, spaceport/near the Savage Chicken/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: No worries. Hazel will start calling you Ms. Ambrose once she sees other people doing it.
DOGGY!
DOGGY!
Or she may backslide.

650.place: >, spaceport/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Do you get that 'doggy' thing from robots a lot?
So far, almost every one.
That's not right. You should tell them to stop.
I don't think it's a problem. They only do it when they first meet me, then they stop.
Unlike this little one who seems caught in an endless loop.
DOGGY! DOGGY! DOGGY!

651.place: short time later, spaceport/on the way to go shopping

dialog.character: All the robots {including one later known as Edge}
dialog.text: DOGGY!
I know you meant it rhetorically, but you're right. That is freaky.

652.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: You certainly attract a lot of attention.
I'm afraid so.
If it makes you nervous, I can move further away.
Nervous? Oh, no. I like this.
It's been years since every head turned my way when I enter a room.

653.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Do crowds make you nervous?
Cautious would be a better word.
Caution is a good trait for an engineer. It keeps you out of trouble and from diving into things head first.
But you're not an engineer here. You're a commuter. Now is not the time for caution but for boldness and sharp elbows.

654.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Niomi, it's rude to push others out of our way.
If we don't push them, they'll push us. Did you think we'd be able to get to the train by asking nicely?
*a path opens in the crowd of robots and humans, like it did in the Red Sea for Moses.
I do not believe this.
You were willing to believe the worst of people. Why not the best?

655.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Thank you for your kindness. We'll wait our turn like everyone else.
It was nice of them to offer, but it wouldn't be right to cut in front of people who were here before us.
I was about to say there are times when you should ignore rules and social niceties, but that may not be a message I want a large, non-human carnivore to pick up.

656.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: You put a lot of effort into being polite.
Yes. It's how I was raised. And it's a nice shortcut.
Being polite shows support for the social structure, and by extension, the vallues it was built on. People relax when they know we're both playing by the same set of rules.
Except that when it comes to tails, there are no rules.

657.place: >, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Not too bright, grabbing a wolf's tail like that.
Florence was talking about being polite. I don't think he expected an immediate physical attack.
He's lucky she was pulled away before he was really hurt.
Yes, but now for the hard part.
Do I punish Hazel or praise her?
...AND IF YOU PULL THE DOGGY'S TAIL AGAIN, I'LL KICK YOU AGAIN.

658.place: short time later, spaceport/subway station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: I can't believe that guy reached out and grabbed you like that.
Humans like to touch things. You've had two children, you know what I mean.
Oh, definitely. When I was pregnant, complete strangers would come up and put their hand on my stomach.
Hazel tried to kick them, too.
Being able to reach their shins and wearing hard shoes makes all the difference, doesn't it, kid?
YAH!

659.place: short time later, spaceport/in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Mommy! Mommy! I found a head! Can I keep it?
No, you can't keep it. Now go and give it back to the gentlebot who lost it.
He didn't say "Thank You" Mommy.
Don't worry about it, Dear. Some people don't know how to be polite after they've been decapitated.

660.place: short time later, spaceport/in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Why did they chose a wolf to make you? Wouldn't a chimp have been easier?
They... had some problems. Chimpanzees weren't good at understanding the feelings or needs of others. They got upset when contradicted and would scream and throw dung at people when it occured.
Why would anyone want to manufacture a race of sociopaths?
Well, those traits did make them surprisingly good C.E.O.'s.

661.place: >, in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: I've never heard of enhanced chimpanzees.
I'm not surprised. They were made almost a hundred years ago. They were dangerous and never allowed outside the lab except in a controlled environment.
You're not in a lab or a controlled environment.
I'm supposed to be. Ecosystems Unlimited never meant for us to be released to the public.
Somebody made a mistake?
Yes, and we intend to make sure it's a mistake they can be proud of.

662.place: >, town/in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: I think canines were chosen because we're about the same size as you. Medical and food for dogs is already in place. And we're socially compatible.
What's it like walking around with the people that made you? Are we like gods to you?
You'll have to excuse me if I don't hold humans in quite that state of reverence.

663.place: >, town/in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: This is our stop. Before we go any further, I need to ask you a question.
Have you been engineered with any safeguards against harming humans?
Is that important right now?
Of course it's important. We're going shopping! I need to know if you can bite, gouge, and kick with the rest of us.

664.place: short time later, town/in the train/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: My species has been certified by Ecosystems Unlimited as 'human safe'.
That means we do have safeguards that are supposed to keep us from harming humans.
I also know, at least in my case, these 'safeguards' have holes in them big enough to put a planet through.

665.place: >, town/train station/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: I've often thought about telling humans that I've figured out ways around my safeguards. I think they'd be proud, knowing that given the choice between good and evil, I've chosen good.
Look! Frankenstein! A scientist loses control of his creation and it has to be destroyed.
Or this one! A new type of robot can't be controlled, so they blow them up!
On the other hand, there's a lot to be said for being cautious.

666.place: >, town/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: I don't know if I like the idea of you being built with safeguards.
But you are a new species. No one knew how you were going to turn out. It would have been crazy not to have made you without some form of controls.
Non of your safeguards involve exploding, do they? Because if they do, I'm going to ask you to stay off the good furniture.
Perfectly understandable.

667.place: >, town/on the way to go shopping

dialog.text: Ecosystems Unlimited has said we were not made with any type of self destruction device or command.
So, you're like a robot? You can't hurt a human?
